messages.content: This is the first individual therapy session with David. He introduces his current situation—he's 38 years old, married with three young children, and works as a project manager. The primary issue he raises is the growing tension between him and his wife, including frequent arguments, which have become more visible to their children. David is feeling exhausted and overwhelmed by his responsibilities at work and home, which has led to a breakdown in communication with his wife. He mentions that their relationship feels more like a partnership focused on managing the kids and household rather than the connection they once had. David expresses a desire to avoid divorce and fears that the situation may be irreparable, even though he still deeply cares about his wife and misses the connection they once shared.

"Hello, David. Welcome to Shrink.io! Before we start the therapy sessions, I’d like to get to know you a bit better. I’ll ask you a few questions about yourself, and after that, we can begin working on what brought you here. Does that sound okay?"
"Yeah, that sounds fine."
"Great. Let’s start with a basic question. How old are you?"
"What’s your current living situation? Do you live alone, with family, or with roommates?"
"I live with my wife and our three kids. Our oldest is six, the middle one is three, and our youngest is just over a year old."
"You have a full house. How do you feel about your home environment right now?"
[sighs] "It’s…tense. There’s a lot of arguing between me and my wife, and it’s gotten to the point where the kids are starting to notice. I don’t know how we got here, but it’s been rough."
"I can imagine that must be really difficult. We’ll definitely explore that more in a bit. Let’s talk about what you do for work. What’s your job, and how do you feel about it?"
"I’m a project manager for a construction company. I used to really enjoy the work, but lately, with everything happening at home, it’s been harder to focus. I’m just drained."
"It sounds like the stress from home is bleeding into your work life. What does a typical day look like for you, from morning to night?"

"It’s chaotic. I get up early, try to help with the kids, get them ready for school or daycare. Then I head to work, where I’m dealing with deadlines and managing teams. By the time I get home, I’m exhausted, and there’s still dinner, bath time, and bedtime routines. And then, when the kids are finally in bed, that’s when my wife and I usually argue. It’s been like this for months."
"That sounds exhausting, trying to balance everything. Do you have any daily routines or rituals that are important to you, something that helps you unwind?"
"I used to go for runs in the evening, but lately, I haven’t had the energy or the time. By the end of the day, all I want to do is sleep, but even that’s been hard."
"It seems like your self-care routines have taken a back seat to all the other responsibilities and stress. How do you spend your free time, or weekends?"

[laughs softly] "Free time? What’s that? With three kids, there’s not much time to relax. On weekends, we’re usually taking the kids to activities or catching up on chores. My wife and I used to do things together, like going out or even just watching a movie, but now it feels like there’s no time, and even when we do have time, we end up fighting."
"It sounds like your connection with your wife has been strained for a while. How would you describe your social life? Do you spend a lot of time with friends or extended family?"

"Not much, honestly. I used to see friends more often, but with the kids and the tension at home, I haven’t made the effort. I see my parents sometimes, but they don’t live nearby. It’s been pretty isolating."

"That isolation can be tough, especially when things at home feel overwhelming. Are you currently in a relationship? You mentioned your wife earlier—how would you describe the relationship right now?"

[sighs deeply] "We’re married, but it feels like we’re more like roommates these days. We’re constantly fighting, and the word ‘divorce’ came up during our last argument. That really scared me. I don’t want a divorce, but I don’t know how to fix this."
"That must have been hard to hear. We’ll definitely explore that in more depth. Have you experienced any significant physical health issues recently?"
"No major issues, just the usual stress. I’ve been feeling more tired than usual, but I think it’s from all the arguing and lack of sleep."
"That makes sense. Do you have any history of mental health diagnoses or treatments?"
"No, I’ve never really seen a therapist before. This is my first time."
"Are you currently taking any medications?"
"No."
"And you mentioned this is your first time in therapy. What brought you in today? What made you feel like it was time to reach out for help?"

[pauses, sighs] "It’s the fighting. We fight all the time now, even in front of the kids. I never wanted that for them. The last fight we had, it was so bad that my wife actually said the word ‘divorce.’ I don’t want that, but I feel helpless. I don’t know how to make things better."

"Thank you for sharing that, David. It sounds like you’re feeling stuck and unsure of how to move forward. The arguments with your wife seem to be escalating, and the idea of divorce has surfaced, which has understandably shaken you. Let’s begin exploring what’s been happening between you and your wife. Can you tell me about the last argument you had?"

[pauses, reflecting] "It was about something small, honestly. I think one of the kids had spilled something, and I was frustrated from work. I snapped at her, and she snapped back, and before we knew it, we were yelling at each other. The kids were there, watching. I hate that. I don’t want them to grow up seeing us fight."

"It seems like the fights are no longer just about the immediate issue but are becoming more about underlying frustrations. What do you think is beneath these arguments? Is there something that you feel isn’t being expressed?"

"I think we’re both just…tired. She’s tired from taking care of the kids, and I’m tired from work and everything else. We don’t really talk anymore. It’s like we’re just going through the motions, and when something happens—like a spill or a late dinner—it’s like all that frustration comes out in the worst way."

"It sounds like there’s a lot of unspoken stress that’s building up over time, and it comes out in these moments. When you think about the way the arguments have been going, what do you feel during those fights? Is it more anger, frustration, or something else?"

[pauses, frowning] "It’s frustration, definitely. But also…anger. I’m angry at her sometimes, but I’m also angry at myself. I feel like I should be able to handle this better, but I’m not. I feel like I’m failing—at being a husband, at being a dad."

"That feeling of failure must be weighing heavily on you. It sounds like the anger you’re experiencing might be tied to those deeper feelings of helplessness. Would you say that some of the anger you feel toward your wife is really anger at yourself for not being able to fix things?"
[nodding slowly] "Yeah, that sounds right. I don’t know how to fix this, and it’s driving me crazy. I want things to be better, but I don’t know where to start."

"That helplessness is understandable, especially when you’re carrying the weight of trying to keep everything together. Have you been able to talk to your wife about how you’re feeling—about the frustration, the anger, and the fear of things falling apart?"
"Not really. When we try to talk, it usually turns into another fight. It’s like we’re both waiting for the other person to say something wrong, and then we’re back at it again."

"It sounds like the communication between you and your wife has broken down to the point where even attempts to talk escalate into conflict. There might be a lot of unspoken emotions on both sides that are making it hard to truly hear each other. Have there been times in the past when communication was better between the two of you?"

[smiling slightly] "Yeah, before the kids were born, we used to talk about everything. We’d stay up late just talking about life, work, our dreams. But now, we barely talk unless it’s about the kids or something that needs to be done around the house."

"It sounds like you’ve lost that connection, the ability to share openly with each other. The responsibilities of life and raising children seem to have created distance between you. Do you miss those conversations, that connection?"
[sighs deeply] "I do. I miss her. I miss us."

"That longing for connection is a sign of hope, though. It shows that you still care deeply about the relationship, even if things feel distant right now. How do you think your wife feels about the situation? Has she expressed any of her own frustrations or concerns?"

"She’s frustrated too, I know that. She’s told me she feels like I’m not present enough, like I’m always focused on work or too tired to engage with the kids. And she’s right. I come home exhausted, and I just want to shut down. But she’s tired too. I get that, but it’s hard to break out of this cycle."

"It seems like both of you are caught in this cycle of exhaustion and frustration, and it’s leading to a breakdown in communication and connection. Part of what we can work on in therapy is finding ways to rebuild that connection—starting with communication. Do you think there’s space for both of you to express your feelings in a way that doesn’t lead to more conflict?"
[pauses, thinking] "I don’t know. Maybe, if we had some help. I feel like we’ve just forgotten how to talk to each other."

"That’s understandable, given the stress you’ve both been under. Therapy can be a place to start relearning those communication skills and finding ways to express your frustrations and fears without it turning into a fight. It’s not an easy process, but it’s something that can be rebuilt over time. How do you feel about working together with your wife to try and repair the relationship?"
"I want to. I don’t want a divorce, and I don’t want my kids growing up in a broken home. But I’m scared that it’s too late, that we’ve already done too much damage."

"That fear is real, but the fact that you’re here and that you still care about repairing the relationship is a good sign. It’s never too late to try and rebuild, especially when both people are willing to put in the effort. We’ll take this step by step, starting with exploring your feelings and learning to communicate them in a way that fosters understanding rather than conflict. How does that sound?"
[nodding slowly] "It sounds good. I’m willing to try anything at this point."

This is the second individual therapy session with David. He shares that the tension at home has persisted, and both he and his wife are walking on eggshells to avoid arguments. He describes feeling frustrated, resentful, and like a failure as both a husband and father. David also realizes that his frustration toward his wife may be tied to anger at himself for not being able to fix their relationship. He reflects on the high expectations he places on himself, particularly the model of stoic strength he learned from his father. The therapist helps David explore the possibility of starting to express his vulnerabilities and emotions to his wife as a way to reconnect and rebuild communication. David expresses an openness to couples therapy and acknowledges that avoiding vulnerability has created distance in his relationships at home.
"Welcome back, David. How have you been feeling since our last session? Have there been any changes in how you and your wife are interacting at home?"

"Not really. It still feels tense at home. We’re not talking as much, and when we do, it’s either about the kids or something small. I’ve tried to avoid fights, especially in front of the kids, but it’s hard. We’re both walking on eggshells."

"It sounds like the tension is still very present, and both of you are trying to avoid conflict but not addressing the underlying issues. Have there been any moments of connection, or does it feel like the distance is growing?"
"It feels like we’re drifting apart. Even when we’re not fighting, it feels like we’re not really connecting. I don’t know how to get back to where we used to be."

"That disconnection can be really painful, especially when you remember a time when things were different. You mentioned before that your communication has broken down. What do you think would help to begin rebuilding that connection?"

"I don’t know. Maybe if we could have a real conversation without it turning into an argument. But every time we try, one of us says something that sets the other off, and we end up back in the same place."

"It sounds like both of you are feeling triggered during those conversations, which makes it hard to talk openly. When you think about these arguments, what emotions do you feel in those moments? Is it anger, frustration, or something else?"
"Definitely frustration. But also…I don’t know, maybe resentment? I’m frustrated that things aren’t working, but I’m also angry at myself for not being able to fix it."

"That combination of frustration and self-criticism can make it harder to approach these situations with a clear head. The resentment you feel toward yourself may also be contributing to the way you react to your wife. Do you feel like some of the anger directed at her is really about how you’re feeling about yourself?"
[pauses] "Yeah, maybe. I feel like I should be doing more, but I just don’t know what to do. I’m failing as a husband, and that just makes me angry—at myself, at her, at the situation."

"It’s tough when we feel like we’re failing in a role we care about, especially when the frustration builds up. You’re carrying a lot of weight, trying to fix things but not knowing where to start. Do you think your wife feels the same sense of frustration, or does it seem like she’s coming from a different place?"

"She’s frustrated too. She’s told me she feels like I’m not present, that I’m too focused on work or too tired to help out with the kids. I get that. She’s right, but I don’t know how to change things. I’m exhausted by the time I get home."

"It sounds like both of you are dealing with similar frustrations—feeling disconnected, overwhelmed, and unsure of how to fix things. That shared experience might be a place to start rebuilding, acknowledging that both of you are struggling in different ways. How do you feel about the idea of sitting down and discussing how both of you are feeling, without focusing on blame or conflict?"
"I’d like that. But honestly, I don’t know if we can do that without it turning into another fight."

"That’s a valid concern. These kinds of conversations can be really hard when there’s so much tension. We can work on how to approach those discussions in a way that feels safer, so both of you can express how you’re feeling without escalating into conflict. One step might be talking about how you miss the connection, rather than focusing on what’s going wrong. How does that sound?"
[nodding slowly] "Yeah, maybe if we started with that, it would help. I miss her, and I miss how things used to be. I don’t think she knows that."

"That’s a powerful starting point—expressing that you miss her and that you still care about the relationship. Often, when we’re stuck in conflict, it’s easy to lose sight of the fact that both people want things to improve. Do you think she feels the same way, even if it’s hard to see right now?"
"I think so. I hope so. She’s brought up the idea of counseling before, but I didn’t take it seriously. Maybe I should have."

"It sounds like she’s also looking for ways to improve things, even if it hasn’t been easy to communicate that. Therapy can be a space where both of you can start that process together. How do you feel about the idea of couple’s therapy, in addition to our sessions here?"
"I’m open to it. If it helps, I’m willing to try anything. I just don’t want us to keep going down this road."

"It’s encouraging that you’re open to the idea. Couple’s therapy can be a way to rebuild communication in a neutral space, but we can also continue working here on how you feel individually. I’m hearing that your frustration isn’t just with the situation but also with yourself. What kind of expectations do you have for yourself as a husband and father?"

"I don’t know. I feel like I should be doing more. I should be more present with the kids, help my wife more, and stop bringing work stress home. But I’m so tired all the time, and I don’t know how to balance it all."

"It sounds like you’re holding yourself to very high standards—wanting to be everything for everyone. That pressure can be overwhelming, especially when you don’t feel like you have the energy to meet those expectations. Where do you think those expectations are coming from?"

[pausing, thinking deeply] "I guess a lot of it is from my dad. He always worked hard and took care of the family, but he never really showed his emotions. I feel like I’m supposed to be like that—always strong, always in control. But I’m not."

"It seems like you’ve internalized a model of being the provider and protector, but without the space to express your own vulnerabilities or emotions. That can be a heavy burden to carry, especially when you’re not feeling as strong or in control as you think you should be. How do you think that’s impacting the way you relate to your wife and kids?"
"I think it’s making things worse. I’m so focused on keeping it together that I end up shutting down, and then I’m not really present with them. I guess I’m scared of showing weakness."

"That fear of vulnerability can create distance, even when you’re physically present. It’s understandable to want to be strong for your family, but part of being strong is also allowing yourself to express what you’re feeling. Do you think there’s room to start being more open with your wife about how overwhelmed you’re feeling?"
"I guess so. I’ve never been good at talking about my feelings, but maybe that’s part of the problem."

"It’s a skill that can take time to develop, especially if you weren’t used to seeing it growing up. But opening up to your wife about what you’re going through—without feeling like you have to solve everything—could help bridge the gap between you. How do you feel about trying that?"
"I’m nervous, but I’ll try. I think we need it, for both of us."

This is the third individual therapy session with David. He discusses how the financial aspects of divorce are weighing heavily on him, adding to the emotional burden of his strained relationship. David feels trapped between the emotional toll of staying in a tense marriage and the financial consequences of divorce, including child support and alimony. He expresses a desire to repair the relationship but feels uncertain whether too much damage has already been done. David struggles to have meaningful conversations with his wife without them escalating into arguments and feels distant from her emotionally. The therapist introduces the idea of setting intentional times for conversations, focusing on building healthier communication, and addressing emotional triggers. David expresses a willingness to try, but he is unsure how to start without causing more conflict.

"Welcome back, David. How have you been feeling today? Have you had any more thoughts about our last session, where we discussed both the emotional and financial aspects of the potential for divorce?"

[nodding slowly] "Yeah, I’ve been thinking about it a lot. The financial part really scares me. I’ve been looking into things like alimony and child support, and the numbers are overwhelming. I know I need to do something, but it feels like whatever path I take is going to be painful—either financially or emotionally."

"It sounds like the financial side of divorce has been weighing heavily on your mind. You’re in a position where you’re trying to balance the emotional impact of the situation with the potential financial fallout. How does that affect the way you’re approaching your marriage right now?"

"Honestly, it makes everything feel more high-stakes. Every fight feels like it’s leading closer to that decision, and the thought of splitting up scares me, especially when I think about how it could affect the kids. The financial part is just the icing on the cake—alimony, dividing assets, custody—it’s a nightmare. But then, staying together and continuing to fight all the time isn’t good either."

"You’re caught between two very difficult paths, and both have serious consequences for your family, your emotions, and your finances. That’s a lot of pressure. When you think about the financial aspects of divorce—like alimony and custody—how does that influence the emotional side of things for you?"

"It adds to the frustration, definitely. It makes me feel trapped, like there’s no good way out. On one hand, I don’t want to keep fighting and making life harder for everyone. But on the other hand, the idea of divorce—of losing time with my kids, of being financially drained—feels just as bad. It’s like I can’t win."

"That sense of feeling trapped can intensify the emotional burden. Both paths—staying in the marriage or divorcing—seem to carry heavy costs, and it’s understandable that you’re feeling stuck. Let’s talk about the potential for repair in the relationship. Do you feel there’s still a part of you that wants to work things out with your wife, despite these challenges?"

[pauses, thinking deeply] "Yeah, part of me does. I don’t want to give up on us, especially for the kids. And I miss her. I miss what we had before. But I also wonder if we’ve done too much damage already. Can we really come back from this?"

"That uncertainty is very real, and it’s normal to question whether the relationship can be repaired after everything that’s happened. One thing we can focus on is small, incremental changes—rebuilding trust, improving communication, and addressing the underlying issues. It’s not a quick fix, but it can help you both reconnect, little by little. How do you feel about taking those small steps?"
"I’m willing to try. I just don’t know if she’s in the same place. She seems so distant now, like she’s already checked out of the relationship."

"It’s difficult when you sense that distance, especially when it feels like you’re the only one still trying. It’s important to gauge where she’s at emotionally, too. Would you be open to having a conversation with her about where both of you stand and what, if anything, you’d like to work on?"
"Yeah, but that’s part of the problem. Every time I try to bring it up, it turns into a fight. I don’t know how to talk about it without us both getting defensive."

"That’s understandable. These conversations are incredibly charged, especially when there’s so much at stake emotionally and financially. One thing we can work on is creating a framework for these conversations—setting boundaries and having clear intentions before diving in. This way, both of you can express yourselves without feeling attacked or defensive. Would you like to explore how to approach that?"
"Yeah, I think that might help. It’s worth a shot, at least."

"A good starting point might be finding a neutral time to talk when neither of you is feeling emotionally triggered. Have you noticed that the conversations tend to start when one or both of you are already upset?"
"Definitely. It’s usually at the end of the day when we’re both exhausted, and something small sets it off."

"It sounds like the timing of these conversations is playing a big role in escalating the tension. What if you planned to talk at a time when you’re both feeling more rested, or even set a specific time to have these conversations?"
"I guess we could try that. Maybe talking in the middle of the day would help, rather than waiting until we’re both at our breaking points."

"That could make a big difference. Being intentional about when and how you have these conversations can help create a safer space for both of you to express your concerns. It may not solve everything right away, but it’s a step toward building healthier communication."
"Yeah, it feels like a start. I’ll try that next time we need to talk."

"And in the meantime, we can continue working on understanding where your emotional triggers come from and how they’re impacting your relationship. There’s a lot to unpack, but taking things one step at a time can help ease some of the pressure. How do you feel about continuing to explore these issues in our sessions?"
"I think that’s a good idea. I feel like I’ve been holding onto a lot, and it’s all coming out in the worst ways."

"That makes sense, David. We’ll work on creating space for you to express what you’re holding onto and start identifying where some of that pressure is coming from. I think that will help you feel more in control of how you respond, both to your wife and to the situation in general."
"Yeah, I’m ready for that. It feels like a lot, but I think I need to face it."

"Facing these feelings is important, and you don’t have to do it all at once. Breaking things down into smaller steps can make it easier to handle. For now, what would you say is the most immediate issue that’s on your mind?"
"Probably the financial stuff. It’s been weighing on me, and I can’t stop thinking about what it’ll mean for the kids. I just keep worrying about how I’ll support two households."

"That’s a legitimate concern. Divorce can have significant financial consequences, especially when it involves supporting two households and the costs of alimony and child support. Have you thought about speaking with a financial advisor to explore your options?"

"I’ve thought about it, but I haven’t done anything yet. I guess I’m avoiding it because it feels like admitting defeat. Like, if I start planning financially, it means I’m giving up on the marriage."

"That’s an understandable fear, but looking into the financial aspect doesn’t necessarily mean you’re giving up. It can be a way of being prepared for whatever outcome happens, whether it’s divorce or staying together. How do you feel about the idea of getting more information, even just as a precaution?"
"I think it would help, but it still feels like a big step. I don’t know if I’m ready to face it yet."

"That’s okay. It’s important to move at your own pace, and you don’t have to rush into anything. Taking small steps, like just gathering information, could help you feel more in control without making any final decisions. Would that feel more manageable?"
"Yeah, I guess that would be a good place to start. I don’t have to make any big decisions right away, but at least I’ll know what to expect."

"Exactly. Having that information can reduce some of the uncertainty you’re feeling. And as we continue working through these issues, you can explore both the emotional and financial sides with more clarity. It’s about preparing yourself for whatever direction things might go."
"I think that’s the right approach. I don’t want to feel like I’m in the dark anymore."

"That’s a great insight, David. We’ll keep working on bringing more light to these issues, step by step. There’s no rush, and you’ll get there when you’re ready. How do you feel after today’s session?"
"Honestly, I feel a bit lighter. Just talking about it helps take some of the weight off."

This is the fourth individual therapy session with David. He reflects on the financial stress that divorce would bring and the emotional strain of trying to reconnect with his wife. David attempted to bring up serious topics with his wife, but she shut down, leaving him feeling helpless. He discusses his fear of making things worse by pushing her too hard and acknowledges that avoidance has led to further disconnection. The therapist helps David understand the need for small, vulnerable steps, such as expressing that he misses the connection with his wife. David agrees to try a new approach—starting with sharing his feelings rather than discussing divorce or practical issues. He expresses nervousness but also readiness to take that step and hopes that expressing his emotions will help reopen communication with his wife.
"Welcome back, David. How are you feeling after our last conversation about the financial aspects of your situation and the pressure it’s putting on you?"

"I’ve been feeling a little better, actually. Talking things through helped me feel less overwhelmed. But it’s still on my mind, especially when I think about the kids and what a divorce would mean for them."
"It’s understandable that the thought of divorce is weighing heavily on you, especially with the impact it could have on your children. Have you been able to talk to your wife about any of this yet?"
"Not really. We’ve been avoiding the big conversations. I tried bringing it up once, but it didn’t go well. She just shut down, and I didn’t push it."
"That can be really frustrating, especially when you feel like these conversations need to happen but can’t find the right way to approach them. How did you feel when she shut down?"
[sighs] "Helpless, honestly. I want to fix things, but when she shuts down, I feel like there’s no way forward. I don’t want to push her and make things worse, but I don’t know what else to do."

"That feeling of helplessness can make it hard to know how to approach the situation. It sounds like you’re trying to be careful not to escalate things, but the avoidance is also leaving you stuck. How do you think she’s feeling about the situation?"

"I think she’s scared, too. She doesn’t want to talk about it, but I can tell she’s thinking about it. She’s worried about the kids and probably the same financial stuff that I am. But instead of talking about it, she’s just avoiding me."

"It seems like both of you are stuck in a pattern of avoidance, which is understandable given how difficult the situation is. But it’s also preventing the two of you from addressing the issues directly. Do you think there’s a way to break through that, or do you feel too caught in the cycle right now?"
"I feel like we’re just stuck. I don’t know how to break the cycle. Every time I try to talk, it feels like the tension rises, and I back off. It’s like walking on a tightrope."

"That sense of walking on a tightrope, where you’re constantly trying to balance without tipping into conflict, must be exhausting. Do you think she’s feeling the same way—trying to avoid conflict but feeling the pressure beneath the surface?"
"Yeah, I think so. We’re both just tired of fighting. But avoiding it isn’t making anything better either."

"Exactly. Avoidance can sometimes feel like a way to keep the peace, but it often leads to more tension building up over time. When you think about the last time you tried to have a serious conversation, what do you think might have triggered her to shut down?"

"I don’t know. I think I might’ve pushed too hard too quickly. I went straight into the tough stuff—talking about divorce and what that would mean. I guess I was just trying to get it all out there, but maybe it was too much for her at once."

"It sounds like the conversation moved quickly into territory that felt overwhelming for both of you. Sometimes, approaching these topics gradually can help ease into the more difficult conversations. Have you thought about starting with smaller steps, like talking about your feelings of disconnection first, before diving into the bigger issues like divorce?"

"That makes sense. I guess I wanted to get everything out in the open, but I can see now that maybe it was too much too soon. I could try starting with how I’ve been feeling and see if that opens things up."

"That sounds like a good approach. Focusing on your feelings—like missing the connection you once had—can create a safer space for both of you to start talking without immediately triggering defenses. Do you feel ready to try that?"
"Yeah, I think so. I’ve been holding a lot in, and maybe if I start by sharing how I feel, she’ll be more open to talking, too."

"It’s definitely worth trying. Starting with vulnerability can sometimes invite the other person to open up as well. And remember, it doesn’t have to be a perfect conversation. What matters is that you’re trying to reconnect, step by step. How do you think you might begin that conversation?"
"I think I’ll start by telling her how much I miss her. How I miss the way things used to be. I don’t know if she’ll want to hear it, but I need to say it."

"That sounds like a heartfelt way to begin. It shows that you care and that you’re not giving up on the relationship. Even if she’s not ready to engage fully at first, just hearing that from you could make a difference. How does it feel to imagine saying that to her?"
[pauses] "It feels a little scary, honestly. But it also feels right. I need to be honest about how I feel."

"That fear is natural, but it sounds like you’re ready to face it. Being honest with her, even if it feels vulnerable, is a big step toward breaking the cycle of avoidance. What do you think might happen if she doesn’t respond the way you hope?"
"I guess I’d feel disappointed, but at least I’d know I tried. I can’t control how she reacts, but I can control how I approach it."

"That’s an important realization—you can’t control her reaction, but you can take responsibility for how you show up. And even if the conversation doesn’t go perfectly, it’s a starting point. What do you hope she takes away from this conversation?"
"I hope she understands that I’m not giving up. That I still care about us, and I want to work things out. I just don’t know how to do it without talking."

"That’s a powerful message. It’s about showing her that you’re still invested in the relationship, even when things are tough. Letting her know that you’re open to working through it together could help start rebuilding that trust. Do you feel ready to take that step?"
"Yeah, I think I am. It’s time to stop avoiding it and start talking."

"It takes courage to face those difficult conversations, but avoiding them is only prolonging the strain. Starting with expressing how much you miss her could be a way to reopen the door to communication. How do you think she might react if you approached the conversation with this angle?"
"I think she’ll be surprised. I don’t know if she expects me to say something like that. We’ve both been so caught up in the daily grind and the arguments that maybe she forgot that I still care."

"That’s an important insight. Sometimes, when conflict builds up, it can overshadow the deeper feelings that both people still care about each other. Do you think expressing that care and concern might help shift the dynamic between you two?"
"I hope so. I don’t want to keep arguing, and I don’t want to keep feeling like we’re on opposite sides. If we can reconnect, even just a little bit, it could make a big difference."

"Reconnecting emotionally, even in small ways, is often the first step toward repairing a relationship. It shows that the relationship still matters to both of you. If you find that the conversation isn’t going as you hope, how do you plan to handle that?"
[pauses] "I guess I’ll try not to take it personally. If she shuts down again, I won’t push it. I’ll just let her know I’m here when she’s ready to talk."

"That sounds like a healthy approach. Giving her space while still showing that you’re available to talk can help avoid pushing her into a defensive position. It’s a delicate balance, but it sounds like you’re thinking carefully about how to approach it."
"Yeah, I want to be patient. I know she’s feeling overwhelmed, just like I am."

"Patience is key in these situations. And you’re showing a lot of self-awareness in recognizing that this won’t be a quick fix. It’s about rebuilding trust and communication over time. How do you feel about where you are in this process right now?"
"I feel like I’m ready to try something different. I don’t want to keep avoiding everything. Even if it’s uncomfortable, I need to take that step."

"That’s a great place to be—recognizing that change requires action, even if it feels uncomfortable. You’re making progress just by being open to trying something new. How do you feel about starting with this conversation as your next step?"
"I think it’s the right move. It’s time to stop avoiding things and start being more honest."

In session 5, David reflects on a recent conversation with his wife where he tried to open up emotionally, telling her that he misses her. While the conversation didn’t escalate into a fight, David was disappointed that his wife didn’t engage deeply. She responded calmly but remained distant, and David expresses frustration at not knowing what she’s truly feeling. The therapist guides David in recognizing that his wife may be protecting herself emotionally, perhaps avoiding deeper conversations to avoid further conflict. The therapist suggests that David continue to create space for open dialogue without pressure, and they discuss the emotional exhaustion David is feeling. The therapist encourages David to continue making small steps toward connection and also to prioritize self-care, even in small increments.
"Welcome back, David. How are things since our last session? Were you able to have that conversation with your wife?"
"Yeah, I did. It didn’t go exactly how I’d hoped, but it wasn’t a disaster either. I tried to open up, telling her how much I missed her, but she didn’t really say much in response."
"That must’ve been frustrating, especially when you took a big step by opening up like that. What was her reaction when you told her how you were feeling?"
[sighs] "She just kind of nodded and said she understood. But it didn’t go deeper than that. I guess I was expecting more… like, I wanted her to engage more, but I didn’t want to push her either."
"It sounds like you were hoping for a more reciprocal conversation, where she shared her feelings as well. Did you sense any emotion from her while she was listening to you?"
"I think she was trying, but it’s hard to tell with her sometimes. She’s not very expressive when it comes to emotions. I could see she was thinking, but she didn’t say much."
"That can make it difficult, especially when you’re hoping for more of a dialogue. Do you think she might have been unsure of how to respond?"
"Maybe. I know she’s not great at talking about feelings, but I hoped that maybe me starting would help her open up too."

"It’s understandable that you were hoping to break the ice with your own openness. Even though the conversation didn’t go exactly as planned, it’s still a positive step. How did it feel for you to share your feelings with her?"
"It felt good to get it out there, but it also felt a bit awkward. Like, I wasn’t sure if I was saying the right things or if I was pushing too hard."

"It’s natural to feel uncertain, especially when these kinds of conversations are new territory. You’ve been avoiding these talks for a while, so the discomfort makes sense. What do you think might be holding her back from engaging more?"
"I’m not sure. Maybe she’s afraid of where the conversation will lead, like we’ll end up fighting again. Or maybe she just doesn’t want to deal with the deeper issues yet."

"That fear of conflict might be playing a big role. If she associates these conversations with past fights, it could make her hesitant to dive into deeper emotions. Did you notice any tension or defensiveness in her body language?"
"Not really. She seemed calm, just distant. I don’t think she was defensive, just… closed off."
"It sounds like there’s a protective barrier, where she’s present but not fully engaged. Do you think she’s trying to protect herself emotionally?"
"Yeah, that could be it. She’s been hurt in the past, and I guess she doesn’t want to go there again."

"That’s a very real possibility. Sometimes, people distance themselves emotionally as a way of avoiding pain. It’s her way of coping, but it also keeps her from connecting fully. How did you handle the end of that conversation?"
"I just told her I was there for her whenever she was ready to talk. I didn’t want to force anything."
"That sounds like a thoughtful approach—giving her space while also showing that you’re available when she’s ready. It’s important to find that balance. How do you feel about where things stand now?"
"I feel a bit stuck, honestly. Like, I’ve made a move, but I don’t know where to go from here."
"It’s understandable to feel stuck. You took a big step, but the process of rebuilding communication and trust takes time. What do you think the next step might look like?"
"I don’t know. Maybe I’ll try again, but I don’t want to keep feeling like I’m talking to a wall."
"That frustration is valid. It’s important to pace these conversations so they don’t feel forced or one-sided. What do you think would make you feel more confident in trying again?"
"Maybe if I had a better sense of what she’s thinking. I’m kind of in the dark right now."
"It sounds like you’re looking for more clarity from her, to understand where she’s at emotionally. Would you be open to asking her more directly about how she’s feeling?"
"I’m open to it, but I’m not sure how to ask without sounding pushy."

"It’s a delicate balance, but it could be as simple as checking in—asking her how she’s feeling about things in general, without putting too much pressure on specific answers. How do you think she’d respond to that?"
"I think she’d be more comfortable with that. I’ll give it a try and see where it goes."

"That sounds like a good plan. Keep the conversation light at first, and give her the space to share at her own pace. In the meantime, how are you feeling about your own emotional space in this process?"
"I feel like I’m doing what I can, but it’s exhausting. I’m trying to keep things together for the kids, but sometimes it feels like too much."
"That emotional toll can add up, especially when you’re trying to hold everything together. It’s okay to acknowledge that exhaustion. Have you been able to find any moments of relief for yourself?"
"Not really. Between work and the kids, there’s not much time for that."

"It’s important to carve out even small moments for yourself, whether it’s a walk, reading, or just some time to unwind. Self-care is crucial, especially when you’re dealing with so much stress. How do you feel about making time for yourself?"
"It’s hard to prioritize that, but I know I need to."

"Even a small step—like 15 minutes of quiet time—can make a difference. Taking care of your own mental space will help you stay more present in your relationships. Do you think you can find a way to fit that in?"
"Yeah, I’ll try. I need to start somewhere."

"That’s a great mindset—starting small and building from there. We’ll keep exploring these conversations with your wife, but also making sure you’re taking care of your own emotional needs along the way."

In session 6, David reports that he approached his wife with a softer conversation, asking her how she was feeling. While the discussion felt less tense than previous ones, David expresses that his wife is still distant, and they haven’t addressed the deeper issues in their marriage. The therapist discusses the importance of allowing his wife space while continuing to express his availability for deeper conversations. David expresses feelings of being in limbo, and the therapist reassures him that small moments of connection, even just laughing together, are steps in the right direction. The therapist emphasizes the importance of self-care, which David acknowledges he has neglected. David shares that he went for a walk recently, and the therapist encourages him to continue finding small moments for himself as part of managing the stress.
"Good to see you again, David. How have things been since our last session? Did you manage to find time to talk with your wife again?"
"Yeah, I tried. I approached her differently this time, like we talked about—just checking in, asking how she was feeling. It went a little better, but she still didn’t open up much."
"That’s good to hear that you approached the conversation in a softer way. How did it feel for you this time around, compared to the last attempt?"
"It felt less tense, which was good. I wasn’t expecting too much, so I guess I wasn’t as disappointed when she didn’t say much. But I still feel like we’re walking around the bigger issues."

"It sounds like the lowered expectations helped you stay calm, even though the depth of the conversation didn’t quite reach where you want it to go yet. Do you think she’s feeling the same reluctance to get into the deeper topics?"
"Yeah, I think so. She seems like she’s avoiding it on purpose. Maybe she’s scared of what could come out if we really dig into everything."

"That fear could definitely be a factor. When a relationship has been through a lot of tension, avoiding deeper conversations can feel safer, even though it leaves things unresolved. Did you notice any changes in her body language or mood when you talked this time?"
"She seemed a bit more relaxed, but still distant. Like she was there physically, but not really engaged emotionally."
"It seems like there’s a guardedness, where she’s keeping her emotions at a distance. What do you think would make her feel more comfortable opening up?"
"I don’t know. Maybe if I kept things really light for a while, she’d feel safer. But I don’t want to avoid the important stuff forever."

"It’s a tough balance between giving her space and eventually addressing the deeper issues. It might help to let her know that you’re ready to talk whenever she is, without pressuring her. That way, the door is open when she feels ready. How would you feel about that?"
"I like that idea. It takes some of the pressure off her, and I guess it takes some of the pressure off me too."

"Exactly. It can help create a more open space for both of you, without either of you feeling cornered into a heavy conversation. How are you feeling in the meantime, with things still up in the air?"
"I’m doing okay, but it’s hard to keep going without any real progress. I’ve been focusing on the kids and trying to keep things stable at home, but it feels like we’re in limbo."

"That feeling of being in limbo can be draining, especially when you’re working hard to maintain stability. Have you found any small moments of connection with your wife, even outside of the deeper conversations?"
"A little bit. We’ve had a few moments where we’ve laughed about something the kids did, but it’s been pretty surface level."

"Even those small moments of connection are important. They might feel minor, but they can help lay the foundation for more meaningful communication later. How do you feel when you have those lighter moments with her?"
"I feel good, like maybe we can still find common ground. But then it’s back to the usual distance."

"Those moments of laughter and connection show that there’s still a part of the relationship that’s intact, even if it’s not as deep as you’d like right now. It’s a reminder that things aren’t entirely broken. How do you feel about building on those lighter moments?"
"I think that could work. If we can laugh together, maybe that’s a way to ease into bigger conversations later."

"That’s a great way of looking at it. Building on those lighter moments can help rebuild trust and emotional closeness, which can make the deeper conversations feel less intimidating when the time comes. How do you plan to continue fostering those moments?"
"I think I’ll keep trying to find those little opportunities—whether it’s watching a movie together or just joking about something. It feels like a small step, but maybe it’ll help."

"It sounds like a thoughtful approach. Small steps can eventually lead to bigger changes, especially when it comes to emotional closeness. Have you had any other thoughts or concerns come up since our last session?"
"Not really. I’ve just been focused on keeping things stable and trying not to push too hard. It’s still a lot to handle, though."

"It’s clear you’re doing your best to navigate a difficult situation, and it’s understandable that it feels overwhelming at times. Have you been able to take any of that personal time for yourself that we discussed?"
"I’ve tried. I went for a walk one night after the kids were in bed. It was nice to get some space, but it’s hard to make that a regular thing."

"It’s good that you took that step, even if it’s just a small start. Finding those moments for yourself is important for your emotional well-being. Do you think you can continue finding time, even if it’s just once or twice a week?"
"I’ll try. I know I need it, but it’s tough to prioritize myself when everything feels so chaotic."

"That’s understandable. It’s easy to let self-care fall by the wayside when you’re focused on everyone else. But remember, taking care of yourself will ultimately help you be more present for your family. How do you feel about making that a goal for the next week?"
"I think I can do that. I’ll try to set aside some time, even if it’s just 20 minutes here and there."

"That sounds like a realistic goal. We’ll keep building on that, just like we’re building on the lighter moments with your wife. It’s all part of the process of taking small, meaningful steps toward change."
"Yeah, it feels good to have a plan, even if it’s just small steps for now."
"Small steps can lead to big changes over time. We’ll keep working on this, and see how things progress with your wife as well. I’m confident that you’re moving in the right direction."

In session 7, David reflects on a small moment of connection he shared with his wife while watching a movie with their kids, which led to some laughter. However, he expresses frustration that, despite these lighter moments, the emotional distance between them remains. The therapist explores David’s deeper feelings of emotional abandonment and highlights how David’s tendency to take on the emotional weight of the relationship may stem from earlier family dynamics, where he often supported his mother emotionally. David begins to realize that this pattern has played out in his marriage, where he feels responsible for maintaining the emotional stability of the relationship. They discuss how David’s role as the “strong” one might be preventing his wife from seeing his own emotional needs. The therapist suggests that David consider being more vulnerable with his wife and perhaps bringing this dynamic into joint therapy. David expresses nervousness but is open to trying this approach.
"Good to see you again, David. How have things been since our last session? Did you manage to find any more moments of connection with your wife?"
"Yeah, a little bit. We had a nice moment watching a movie together with the kids, and there was some laughter. It felt good, but still… there’s this distance between us, like we’re just coexisting."
"That moment of laughter with the kids—it must have felt good to experience a lighter moment. What was it like for you, emotionally, to have that glimpse of connection again?"
"It was nice, for sure. It reminded me of how things used to be. But it’s bittersweet, because right after, it felt like nothing had really changed."

"I hear you. Sometimes those small moments give us a taste of what we’re missing, and it makes the distance feel even sharper. When you think about those old feelings of closeness, what memories come to mind?"

[pauses] "I guess… when we first started dating, it was different. We used to talk about everything. Life, dreams, little stuff that didn’t matter. Now it feels like we barely talk at all unless it’s about the kids."

"It sounds like you’re mourning the loss of that emotional connection—the ability to share freely and feel understood. Do you think there’s a part of you that’s feeling abandoned emotionally, like your needs aren’t being met?"
"Yeah, definitely. I feel like I’m always the one trying to fix things, but I don’t get much back. It’s like I’m carrying the whole weight of the relationship."

"That’s a heavy burden to carry alone. And it makes me wonder if some of the pressure you’re feeling now might be linked to earlier experiences, perhaps even growing up. Were there times when you felt like you had to carry more than your share emotionally?"

[pauses, thinking] "I guess with my dad, yeah. He was always working, so I ended up being the one who took care of things at home a lot. My mom leaned on me for support, especially when things were tough with him."

"It sounds like you learned early on how to take responsibility for emotional stability in the family. Do you think some of those old patterns might be playing out in your marriage now—feeling like it’s your job to hold things together?"
"I hadn’t thought of it that way, but yeah, maybe. I do feel like I have to keep things from falling apart, for the kids and for us."

"That makes sense. It can be hard to break free from those early patterns, especially when they’ve been part of your identity for so long. Do you ever feel resentment toward your wife for not sharing that emotional load?"
[sighs] "Yeah, I guess I do. It feels unfair sometimes, like I’m the only one trying. But then I feel guilty for even thinking that way."

"It’s important to recognize that both feelings—resentment and guilt—can coexist. The guilt might come from that part of you that’s used to being the caretaker, but the resentment is valid, too. You’re allowed to have needs in this relationship."
"I don’t want to push her, though. She’s been through a lot, too, and I don’t want to add more pressure."

"I understand your concern. But it might be helpful to consider whether this dynamic—where you take on the emotional weight and she stays more distant—is something you’re both stuck in, almost unconsciously. Does it feel familiar in other parts of your life?"
"Yeah, I can see that. Even at work, I’m the guy everyone comes to for support, but I never really ask for anything back."

"That pattern of always being the strong one, the one others lean on—it can be exhausting. It also might make it harder to express your own vulnerabilities. Do you think this could be part of why your wife seems distant? Maybe she’s used to seeing you in that role."
"I hadn’t thought about it like that. Maybe she doesn’t think I need anything because I’m always holding it together."

"Exactly. By holding back your own needs and emotions, you might unintentionally be reinforcing that dynamic. How do you think it would change things if you allowed yourself to be more vulnerable with her, even in small ways?"
"I don’t know. I’ve always been afraid that if I let down my guard, everything will fall apart."

"That fear makes sense, especially given your past experiences. But being vulnerable doesn’t mean losing control—it’s about letting her see that you have emotional needs, too. What would it be like to start by expressing those needs in a joint session here, with both of you present?"
"I’m not sure how she’d react to that. She’s not one to open up in front of strangers."

"It could feel intimidating for her, especially if she’s used to avoiding emotional conversations. But it might also give you both a safe space to start reconnecting, with me helping guide the conversation. How do you feel about suggesting it?"
"I think it could help. But I’m worried she’ll feel ambushed, like I’m trying to fix her."

"That’s a fair concern. You could present it as a chance for both of you to work together on understanding each other better, not just about fixing problems. It’s about creating a space where both of you can feel heard and supported."
[nodding] "I’ll give it some thought. It feels like a big step, but maybe it’s what we need."
"It’s a big step, but it could be a turning point. Even suggesting it could open up a new conversation between you two about where you both stand emotionally."
"Yeah, I think it’s worth a shot. I just don’t want to make things worse."

"I understand the hesitation. But remember, opening up doesn’t mean everything has to be perfect right away. It’s about taking small steps toward rebuilding that connection, even if it feels uncomfortable at first."
"I’ll try. I don’t want to keep going in circles like this."

In session 8, David shares his disappointment after suggesting a joint session to his wife, who declined the offer, saying they need to figure things out on their own. David is frustrated and feels like he’s the only one trying to fix the marriage. The therapist helps David explore the deeper fears his wife might have, such as vulnerability and the fear of confronting their issues. David admits feeling resentment toward her for not putting in the same effort, which he realizes might be causing him to pull back emotionally. The therapist encourages David to continue engaging without expecting immediate results and suggests focusing on smaller moments of connection. They also discuss the importance of setting emotional boundaries to prevent burnout.
"Good to see you again, David. How have things been since our last session? Were you able to talk to your wife about the idea of having a joint session?"

[sighs] "Yeah, I brought it up. It didn’t go as well as I hoped. She wasn’t interested. She said she didn’t think talking to someone else would help and that we just need to figure things out on our own."
"That must have been disappointing, especially after you put thought into how to approach it. How did you feel when she said no?"
"I was frustrated. I felt like it was a step we could take, but she just shut it down. It’s like she doesn’t want to try."

"That frustration makes sense, especially since you’ve been the one pushing for change. Do you think her reluctance might be tied to a deeper fear—perhaps of being vulnerable in front of someone else, or even confronting the state of the relationship?"
"Yeah, I think she’s afraid. She doesn’t like talking about emotions, and I guess bringing in a third person makes it even more real."

"It could be that the idea of opening up in therapy feels overwhelming for her. For some people, acknowledging the problems out loud can make them feel more exposed. Do you think that’s part of what’s happening here?"
"Maybe. She’s always been more private about her feelings. It’s hard for her to even talk to me, let alone someone else."

"It sounds like her emotional distance is a protective mechanism. She may not feel safe enough to share her vulnerabilities, even with you. What do you think would make her feel more secure in opening up?"
"I don’t know. I’ve tried being more open myself, but it hasn’t really changed anything. I guess I’m not sure what else to do."

"You’ve been doing a lot of the emotional work on your own, and it’s understandable that it feels exhausting. What’s coming up for you emotionally when you think about her response and the current state of the relationship?"
[pauses] "I guess it’s a mix of sadness and frustration. Sadness because I miss her, but frustration because I don’t know how to fix this. It feels like I’m hitting a wall."

"That’s a powerful combination—missing her while also feeling stuck and powerless. I wonder if there’s a part of you that’s feeling some resentment toward her, for not putting in the same effort you are?"
[nodding slowly] "Yeah, I think so. I don’t like admitting it, but I do feel resentful sometimes. It’s like I’m the only one fighting for this marriage."

"It’s okay to acknowledge that resentment. It’s a normal response when the emotional burden feels unbalanced. How do you think that resentment might be affecting the way you interact with her, even in subtle ways?"
"I think it makes me pull back sometimes. Like, if she’s not trying, why should I? But then I feel guilty because I know I shouldn’t give up."

"That push-and-pull between wanting to keep trying and feeling like you’re carrying the weight alone can create a lot of internal conflict. Do you think your pulling back might be reinforcing the emotional distance between you two?"
"Yeah, I hadn’t thought about it that way, but it probably is. It’s just hard to keep putting myself out there when nothing changes."

"It makes sense that you’d feel hesitant to keep trying, especially when it feels like your efforts aren’t being met halfway. But recognizing how your own responses might be contributing to the dynamic is an important step. What would it look like for you to keep engaging, even when it feels one-sided?"
"I guess it would mean not giving up, even when she pulls away. But that’s tough."

"It’s incredibly tough, and I’m not suggesting you do it without boundaries. It’s about finding a balance between continuing to engage and protecting your own emotional well-being. What boundaries might help you manage that balance?"
"Maybe I need to stop expecting immediate results. I keep thinking one conversation will fix everything, but it doesn’t work like that."

"That’s a good realization. Adjusting your expectations can help reduce some of the frustration. Rebuilding a relationship takes time, and it might help to see each step as part of a longer process. How would it feel to approach the next conversation with fewer expectations?"
"It might help. I think I get disappointed because I’m always hoping for a breakthrough, but maybe I need to take it slower."

"Slowing down and focusing on smaller moments of connection might take some of the pressure off both of you. Do you think it would help to approach her without trying to solve everything at once, and instead just focus on being present together?"
"Yeah, I think that’s a good idea. I’ve been so focused on fixing things that I’ve probably made it feel like too much."

"Exactly. Sometimes the pressure to fix things can create even more tension. What if your goal was just to share a moment with her, without the weight of trying to resolve anything? How do you think that would change the dynamic?"
"I think it would make things feel lighter, less serious. Maybe we could just enjoy being around each other for once, without the pressure."
"That sounds like a healthy shift. Instead of trying to force progress, you can create space for connection to happen naturally. How do you feel about making that your focus for the next week?"
"I can do that. I think it’s worth trying. Maybe if I stop pushing so hard, things will open up on their own."

"It’s definitely worth trying. By letting go of the need for immediate results, you might find that there’s more room for things to evolve at their own pace. And remember, it’s okay to give yourself permission to take things slowly too."
"Yeah, I’ll try. It’s hard to let go of the idea that everything has to be fixed right away, but I’ll work on it."

"It’s a process, and you’re doing important work by even recognizing these patterns. We’ll keep exploring this in our sessions, and see how things progress in the coming weeks. You’re not alone in this."

In session 9, David talks about a recent attempt to be present with his wife, where they watched a show together. While there were no fights, he still felt emotionally distant from her. David admits he often wants to ask difficult questions, like whether his wife is happy, but he holds back out of fear of making things worse. The therapist helps David connect this pattern to his childhood, where he avoided conflict to stay safe. They discuss the need to break this avoidance pattern in his marriage, starting with small, neutral conversations. David expresses concerns that his wife may shut down, but agrees to keep trying, even with lowered expectations. The therapist also emphasizes the importance of continuing self-care to manage David’s emotional exhaustion.
"Welcome back, David. How are things since we last spoke? Have there been any changes in how you and your wife are connecting?"

[sighs] "Not really. I tried to focus on just being present with her, like we talked about. We watched a show together, and there were no fights, but it didn’t feel like we were any closer either. It still feels like we’re just going through the motions."
"That must be frustrating, feeling like you’re trying to stay present but not getting the emotional connection you’re hoping for. What was the atmosphere like when you spent time together?"
"It was… quiet. We weren’t arguing, but we weren’t really talking either. I think she’s still holding back. I know I am, too, because I don’t want to say the wrong thing and make it worse."

"It sounds like there’s still a lot of emotional distance between you, and that fear of saying the wrong thing is keeping you both from engaging fully. Do you think she’s aware of how much you’re holding back?"
"Maybe. She’s probably doing the same thing, though. I feel like we’re stuck in this loop of both avoiding the hard stuff because neither of us wants to start a fight."
"That loop of avoidance can be tough to break, especially when both people are trying to avoid conflict. Do you ever catch yourself wanting to say something but stopping because of that fear?"
"All the time. There are moments where I just want to ask her if she’s happy, or if she even wants to work on this anymore, but then I stop because I’m afraid of the answer."
"That’s a difficult place to be—wanting clarity but also fearing what that clarity might bring. It seems like the uncertainty is just as painful as the idea of potential conflict."
"Exactly. I feel like I’m stuck between wanting to know the truth and being scared that if I ask, it’ll end everything."
"Do you think part of that fear comes from past experiences, where asking difficult questions has led to things falling apart?"
"Yeah, I’ve always avoided tough conversations. Even growing up, I’d keep quiet to avoid making things worse. My parents used to fight a lot, and I’d just stay out of it."

"It sounds like those early experiences of witnessing conflict taught you that staying quiet was safer. Do you see parallels between how you handled things then and how you’re handling things now in your marriage?"
"Yeah, I think so. I’ve always been more comfortable avoiding conflict. But now I’m realizing it’s not really helping. We’re just drifting further apart."

"That realization is important. Avoiding conflict may feel safe in the short term, but it often leads to more distance in the long term. How do you feel about the idea of starting to break that pattern—slowly, and in small ways?"
"I know I need to, but it’s hard. I don’t want to start a fight, but I also don’t want to keep pretending everything’s fine when it’s not."

"It makes sense that you’d feel conflicted. There’s a way to address the distance without jumping straight into confrontation. What if you approached it by asking her how she’s feeling in a more neutral way, rather than diving straight into the harder questions?"
"Maybe. I could ask her how she’s feeling in general, without making it sound like an attack or like I’m accusing her of anything."
"Exactly. It’s about opening the door to communication without putting pressure on her to have all the answers right away. How do you think she might respond to that kind of approach?"
"She might be more willing to talk if I keep it light. But part of me wonders if she’ll just shut down again. That’s what usually happens."

"That’s a valid concern. It’s possible she might not open up right away, especially if she’s used to avoiding emotional conversations. But even just asking the question shows that you’re trying to connect. What would it feel like for you if she doesn’t respond the way you hope?"
"I’d be disappointed, but I think I’m getting used to that. I’ve lowered my expectations a lot recently."

"That disappointment is tough, especially when you’re making an effort to bridge the gap. It’s important to keep in mind that rebuilding communication takes time, and each small step counts, even if it doesn’t feel like immediate progress. How do you feel about continuing to try, even with that uncertainty?"
"I’ll keep trying. I don’t want to give up yet, even though it feels like I’m the only one trying sometimes."
"That persistence is a strength, but it’s also important to take care of yourself in the process. You’ve been carrying a lot emotionally. How are you managing the weight of that on your own?"
[sighs] "I’m tired, honestly. It’s hard to stay positive when I feel like I’m doing this by myself. I’ve been trying to take more time for myself, but it’s not easy."

"That exhaustion is understandable. You’re doing a lot to keep things together, and it’s important to recognize that. Even small moments of self-care can make a difference. What have you been doing to take care of yourself lately?"
"I’ve been trying to get outside more, just going for walks when I can. It helps clear my head a bit, but it’s still hard to relax when everything feels so uncertain."

"It’s good that you’ve been making time for those walks. Even though the uncertainty is still there, finding moments of peace can help you recharge. Do you think you can continue carving out those small moments for yourself?"
"Yeah, I’ll try. I know I need to. It’s just hard to focus on myself when everything else feels so heavy."

"It’s understandable that self-care feels difficult right now. But by taking care of yourself, you’re also building the resilience to keep working through the challenges in your relationship. What’s one small thing you could commit to doing for yourself this week?"
"I’ll try to make time for another walk, maybe even a longer one this time. Just to clear my head."
"That sounds like a good plan. We’ll keep working on balancing the emotional work you’re doing in your marriage with taking care of your own well-being. How do you feel about that?"
"I think it’s necessary. I can’t keep going like this without taking care of myself too."
"Exactly. It’s about finding that balance between showing up for your relationship and taking care of your own emotional needs. We’ll keep exploring this together."

In session 10, David reports that he asked his wife how she was feeling, and she opened up a little, sharing that she was feeling overwhelmed. While it wasn’t a deep conversation, David felt relieved that she engaged at all. The therapist helps David recognize that his wife’s stress is likely contributing to their emotional distance, and they discuss small ways David could support her, such as checking in regularly and helping with the kids. David expresses a sense of relief at having some emotional progress, but admits he’s still feeling tired. The therapist encourages David to continue focusing on small moments of connection while also taking time for himself. They discuss the importance of letting go of the pressure to fix everything immediately and taking the relationship day by day.
"Good to see you again, David. How have things been this past week? Were you able to ask your wife how she’s feeling, like we discussed?"
"Yeah, I did. I kept it light, like we talked about. I asked her how she was feeling in general, and she actually opened up a bit. It wasn’t a deep conversation, but it was better than nothing."
"That’s a positive step. Even if it wasn’t deep, it sounds like she was willing to engage. How did you feel when she opened up?"
"Honestly, it was a relief. She told me she’s been feeling overwhelmed with everything, but she didn’t go into much detail. Still, it was the most she’s said in a while."

"That’s a significant moment, especially considering the emotional distance you’ve been experiencing. It sounds like she might be carrying her own weight of stress. How do you feel about what she shared with you?"

"It made sense, but it also made me realize how little we’ve been talking about what’s really going on with us. I’ve been so focused on the marriage and the kids that I didn’t even notice how overwhelmed she was."
"It can be easy to miss those deeper emotions when both of you have been navigating so much stress. Do you think her feeling overwhelmed might be contributing to the distance between you?"
"Yeah, I think so. She’s been juggling a lot with work and the kids, and I guess I didn’t really see how much it was affecting her."

"It sounds like her stress is playing a big role in the emotional distance between you two. It’s important that you’re becoming more aware of it now. How do you think you could support her more, while also balancing your own needs?"
"That’s the hard part. I want to be there for her, but I’m already feeling stretched thin myself. I don’t want to add more pressure on either of us."

"It’s a delicate balance, for sure. It’s about finding ways to support each other without adding to the stress. What do you think are some small ways you could show support without overwhelming yourself?"
"Maybe just checking in with her more often, asking how her day was, or offering to help with the kids so she can have some time to herself."
"Those are great ideas. Sometimes the small gestures, like checking in or offering help, can make a big difference. How do you think she would respond if you started doing that more consistently?"
"I think she’d appreciate it. She seemed a bit surprised when I asked her how she was feeling, so maybe if I keep doing it, she’ll feel more comfortable opening up."
"That sounds like a solid plan. Building that consistent connection might help her feel safer to share more with you over time. How do you feel about continuing to approach her this way?"
"I feel good about it. It feels like something I can do without adding too much pressure on either of us."
"That’s key—taking small steps toward connection without overwhelming either of you. How are you feeling about your own emotional space right now, with everything you’ve been managing?"
[pauses] "I’m still pretty tired, to be honest. It’s hard to juggle everything, but I feel like I’m in a better place mentally compared to a few weeks ago."

"That’s good to hear. Even though you’re still feeling exhausted, it sounds like you’ve made progress in terms of how you’re managing the emotional load. What do you think has contributed to that shift?"
"I think just talking about it here has helped. It’s made me realize that I don’t have to fix everything right away, and that’s taken some of the pressure off."

"That’s an important shift—realizing that things don’t have to be resolved overnight. It sounds like you’re learning to give yourself more space emotionally, which is a big step. How do you feel about continuing to let go of the pressure to fix everything immediately?"
"I think it’s necessary. I was burning myself out trying to fix everything at once. Now, I’m trying to take it day by day."

"That’s a healthier approach. Taking it day by day allows you to stay present and avoid feeling overwhelmed by the bigger picture. How do you feel about continuing to take small steps toward reconnecting with your wife?"
"I feel like it’s the only way forward. We’ve got a long way to go, but at least we’re talking again, even if it’s just a little bit."

"That’s an important shift. Rebuilding communication is often a slow process, but each conversation is a step in the right direction. How do you think you’ll approach the next week in terms of both supporting her and taking care of yourself?"
"I’ll keep checking in with her and try to be more present. And I’ll keep making time for myself, even if it’s just for a short walk or some quiet time."
"That sounds like a balanced plan. Supporting her while also taking care of your own emotional space will help you stay grounded. How do you feel about the progress you’ve made so far?"
"It’s slow, but I feel like things are moving in the right direction. I just need to keep reminding myself that it’s going to take time."

"Exactly. This kind of progress doesn’t happen overnight, but each small step is meaningful. We’ll keep building on what you’ve started, and continue exploring ways to support both yourself and your relationship. You’re on the right track."
"Thanks. I feel like I’ve got a better sense of where we’re heading now."

In session 11, David talks about how he’s been checking in with his wife more, but they still aren’t having deep conversations. He expresses frustration, feeling like they’re skimming the surface without any breakthroughs. The therapist explores David’s fears about what might happen if they dig deeper emotionally, particularly his fear that his wife may admit she doesn’t love him anymore. They discuss taking small steps to explore deeper emotions without overwhelming either of them, and David identifies a question he’s been wanting to ask his wife—whether she’s still happy in the marriage. The therapist helps David reframe the question in a way that feels less daunting, and they work on preparing him for that conversation, focusing on managing his emotions and taking care of himself in the process.
"Welcome back, David. I know you’ve been taking things step by step with your wife. How have things been progressing this past week? Have you noticed any shifts in your interactions?"

"Yeah, I’ve been checking in with her more, like we talked about. It’s been a bit better. She seems to appreciate it, but we’re still not having any deep conversations. It’s like we’re skimming the surface."

"That’s understandable. It sounds like you’re still working on creating that emotional safety where deeper conversations can happen. How does it feel for you, knowing you’re making progress but not quite reaching the level of depth you’d like?"
"It’s a mix. On one hand, I feel good that we’re not fighting as much, but on the other, I feel like I’m waiting for something bigger to happen, like a real breakthrough."

"That sense of anticipation for a breakthrough can be both motivating and frustrating. It’s important to acknowledge the progress you’ve made, even if it feels slow. What do you think is holding both of you back from going deeper?"
[pauses] "I think part of it is fear. We’re both afraid that if we dig too deep, we’ll uncover things that might make things worse. I know I’m scared of what might come out."

"That fear makes sense. You’ve both been navigating this tension for a while, and it’s natural to be afraid of what might happen if everything comes out. What’s the worst outcome you imagine if you did have that deeper conversation?"
"I guess I’m afraid she’ll say she doesn’t love me anymore or that she wants out. I’ve been holding onto hope that we can fix things, but I’m scared that she’s already given up."

"That fear of losing her is at the heart of this, and it’s something many people feel when they’re on the edge of deeper emotional conversations. What do you think would happen if she did say something like that? How do you imagine you’d respond?"
"I don’t know. I’ve thought about it, but I don’t think I’m ready to face that possibility. It would feel like the end, and I’m not ready for that."

"It’s understandable to feel unprepared for such a possibility. But avoiding these conversations can sometimes keep both people in a place of limbo, unsure of where things stand. How do you feel about taking small steps to explore those deeper emotions without diving in too fast?"
"I think I can handle that, as long as we don’t try to fix everything in one go. I don’t want to overwhelm either of us."

"Exactly. Small steps can create space for emotional connection without forcing either of you to confront everything at once. What’s one question or topic you’ve been wanting to explore with her but haven’t yet because of that fear?"
