[thinks for a moment] "I’ve been wanting to ask her if she’s still happy in this marriage, but I’ve been too afraid to say it. I’m worried about what she’ll say."
"That’s a big question, and it carries a lot of weight. Do you think framing it in a more open-ended way, like asking her how she feels about where the relationship is, might feel less daunting?"
"Yeah, that sounds like it might be easier to ask. It doesn’t feel as loaded as directly asking if she’s happy."
"That’s a great approach. By keeping the question open-ended, you give her the opportunity to share her feelings without feeling cornered. How do you feel about trying that out?"
"I think I’ll give it a try. I’ve been avoiding it for too long, and I need to know how she really feels."

"It’s a courageous step, David, and I think you’re ready to take it. Even though the answer might not be what you hope for, it’s important to get clarity. How do you think you’ll manage your emotions going into that conversation?"
"I’ll try to stay calm, but I know it’s going to be tough. I just have to remind myself that whatever she says, it’s better to know than to keep wondering."

"That’s a strong mindset to have. By staying present and grounded, you’ll be better prepared for whatever response she gives. And remember, even if the conversation doesn’t go as expected, it’s a step toward understanding each other better."
"Yeah, I think I’ve been stuck in this place of uncertainty for too long. I need to break out of it, even if it’s hard."

"That’s a huge realization. Staying in that place of limbo has been taking a toll on you emotionally. By taking this step, you’re allowing both of you to move forward, whether that’s toward resolution or a new direction."
"It’s scary, but I know I have to do it. I’ll feel better knowing where we stand, even if it’s not the answer I want."

"Facing that fear is a powerful move. No matter what happens, you’re building emotional resilience by confronting the uncertainty head-on. How do you feel about your ability to manage whatever outcome comes from this?"
"I think I’ll be okay. It’s going to hurt if she says she’s not happy, but at least I won’t be stuck in this constant worry about the unknown."
"That’s a healthy perspective. The unknown often creates more anxiety than the truth, even if the truth is painful. How do you feel about continuing to focus on self-care as you navigate this?"
"I’ll keep doing what I’ve been doing. The walks help, and I’ve been trying to take some time for myself when I can. It’s not always easy with the kids, but I’m trying."
"That’s great. Even small moments of self-care can make a big difference in how you handle these emotionally charged situations. What’s one thing you can commit to doing for yourself this week?"
"I think I’ll take a longer walk, maybe on the weekend when things are a little quieter. Just to clear my head before I have this talk with her."
"That sounds like a good plan. Giving yourself that space will help you feel more grounded going into the conversation. How do you feel about balancing your needs and your wife’s during this time?"
"It’s hard, but I’m learning to prioritize both. I used to focus only on her, but now I see that I need to take care of myself too."

"That’s a crucial shift. Taking care of yourself doesn’t mean you’re neglecting her—it means you’re building the strength to show up fully for both of you. How do you think this new approach will change the dynamic in your relationship?"
"I think it’ll help. If I’m not so drained all the time, I can be more present for her and the kids. It’s just hard to get used to thinking about my own needs."

"It’s a learning process, and it sounds like you’re making important strides. By giving yourself the space to recharge, you’re also giving your relationship a better chance to grow. How do you feel about continuing to explore this balance in our future sessions?"
"I think it’s necessary. I’ve been so focused on fixing the marriage that I forgot about myself. I need to keep working on that balance."

"We’ll definitely keep working on that. You’re doing incredible work, and each small step you take is building a stronger foundation for both yourself and your relationship. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"
"I feel more ready to face the conversation with her. I’m still nervous, but I know it’s time to stop avoiding it."

"That readiness is a testament to the emotional work you’ve been doing. We’ll continue building on this in our future sessions, and I’m confident you’ll handle the conversation with strength and openness."

In session 12, David shares that he finally had the conversation with his wife about how she feels about the marriage. She admitted that she’s been unhappy for a while, which was painful for David to hear, but also a relief to finally have some clarity. David reflects on his feelings of failure, realizing that he’s been carrying the responsibility of trying to fix everything on his own. The therapist helps him explore how his childhood experiences, particularly with his parents’ conflict, may have shaped his sense of responsibility in relationships. They discuss the importance of letting go of the role of being the fixer and having more conversations with his wife about her willingness to work on the marriage. David expresses his readiness to have that conversation and his commitment to continue focusing on self-care as he navigates these difficult emotions.
"Welcome back, David. Last week you were preparing to have an important conversation with your wife about how she feels about the marriage. How did that go?"
[sighs] "It was tough, but I did it. I asked her how she felt about the relationship, and she admitted that she’s been unhappy for a while. It hurt to hear, but at least I know where she stands now."
"That must have been difficult to hear, but it’s a big step that you had that conversation. How did it feel for you, finally getting that clarity?"

"Honestly, it was a relief, even though it hurt. I’ve been living in this limbo, not knowing where things were headed. Now that I know how she feels, it feels like the uncertainty is gone, but the weight is still there."
"That clarity is important, but I can imagine it brings a new set of emotions now that you know she’s been feeling this way. How are you processing what she shared with you?"

"I’m still trying to wrap my head around it. Part of me feels like I’ve failed her, like I should have done more to make her happy. But another part of me is just… tired, you know? I’ve been trying so hard, but I can’t fix everything on my own."

"That feeling of having failed her must be heavy. It sounds like you’ve been carrying a lot of responsibility for her happiness. Do you think that’s something you’ve always felt in your relationship?"

"Yeah, I guess I’ve always been the one trying to keep things together. Even when we first started having problems, I felt like it was my job to fix it. But now I’m realizing I can’t do it by myself."

"That’s a crucial realization—understanding that you can’t carry the full weight of the relationship alone. Where do you think that sense of responsibility comes from, the feeling that it’s your job to fix things?"

"I think it goes back to my parents. They fought a lot when I was a kid, and I always felt like I had to keep the peace. I’d try to distract them or stay out of their way, but it never really worked."

"It sounds like you learned early on to take on that role of being the one to hold things together, even in situations that were beyond your control. Do you see any parallels between what you experienced with your parents and what’s happening in your marriage now?"
"Yeah, I think so. It’s like I’ve been playing the same role—trying to keep things from falling apart, even when it feels like I’m the only one trying."

"That pattern can be exhausting, especially when it feels like you’re repeating something from your past. How does it feel to recognize that connection between your childhood and your current relationship?"
"It makes sense, but it also feels a bit overwhelming. Like I’ve been stuck in this cycle for years without even realizing it."

"It can be overwhelming to see those patterns, but recognizing them is a powerful step toward breaking the cycle. Now that you’re more aware of it, how do you feel about shifting away from that role of trying to fix everything on your own?"
"It’s hard to let go of, but I know I need to. I can’t keep doing this by myself, especially if she’s not fully in it."

"Letting go of that role is challenging, but it’s also freeing. It allows you to step back and recognize that both partners need to be invested in making things work. How do you feel about having more conversations with her about what she’s willing to put into the relationship?"
"I think I need to have that conversation. It’s clear that things can’t go on like this if she’s not willing to meet me halfway. I need to know if she wants to try or if she’s ready to give up."

"That’s a tough but necessary conversation. It’s important to know whether she’s willing to invest in rebuilding the relationship, especially since you’ve been doing so much emotional work. How do you feel about approaching that conversation?"
"It’s scary, but I think I’m ready for it. I need to know where she stands, and I can’t keep tiptoeing around it."
"That readiness shows how much progress you’ve made. Even though it’s scary, you’re stepping into these conversations with more clarity and strength. How do you think she might respond?"
"I honestly don’t know. She’s hard to read sometimes. I’m hoping she’ll be open to trying, but I’m preparing myself for the possibility that she’s done."
"It sounds like you’re balancing hope with realism, which is important. How do you think you’ll manage your emotions if her response isn’t what you hope for?"
"I think I’ll be okay. I’ve already been preparing for the possibility that things might end. It’ll hurt, but at least I’ll know where we stand."

"That emotional preparation is crucial. You’re allowing yourself to face the possibility of loss, but you’re also giving yourself the space to be okay with whatever comes next. How are you planning to take care of yourself in the lead-up to this conversation?"
"I’ve been trying to make more time for myself, like we talked about. I went for a longer walk this week, and it helped clear my head. I’m planning to do that again before I talk to her."

"That’s great. Creating that space for yourself will help you stay grounded, no matter what happens. How do you feel about balancing self-care with the emotional work you’ve been doing in the relationship?"
"It’s tough, but I’m getting better at it. I’m realizing that I need to take care of myself if I’m going to keep going through all of this."

"That’s an important realization. By taking care of yourself, you’re not only strengthening your own emotional resilience but also creating a healthier foundation for any future conversations with your wife. How do you feel about continuing to make self-care a priority, even as you navigate these tough conversations?"
"I think it’s necessary. I’ve spent so much time focused on the marriage that I forgot about myself. I can’t keep doing that."

"Exactly. By prioritizing yourself, you’re ensuring that you’re emotionally equipped to handle whatever comes next. How do you think this shift in focus will affect the way you approach your marriage moving forward?"
"I think it’ll help. If I’m not so drained all the time, I’ll be able to think more clearly and make better decisions about what’s right for both of us."

"That clarity will make a big difference. By stepping back and allowing yourself to recharge, you’re also allowing the relationship to evolve naturally, without the pressure of trying to fix everything. How do you feel about letting go of that pressure?"
"It’s hard, but I’m starting to get used to it. I think I’ve been holding onto control for so long that it’s weird to let go, but it’s also a relief in a way."

"That relief is important. Letting go of control doesn’t mean you’re giving up—it means you’re allowing space for both of you to figure out what you really want. How do you feel about continuing to approach the relationship with that mindset?"
"I feel like it’s the only way forward. I can’t keep holding on so tightly. If she wants to make this work, she’ll have to meet me halfway."

"That’s a healthy approach. By letting go of the need to control the outcome, you’re giving both of you the space to decide what’s best for your future. We’ll keep exploring this balance in our future sessions. How are you feeling about the progress you’ve made so far?"
"I feel better. I’m still nervous about what’s going to happen, but I feel like I’m in a stronger place emotionally."

"That emotional strength will serve you well, no matter what happens. You’ve done a lot of important work, and you’re continuing to grow through these difficult conversations. We’ll keep building on this progress in the coming weeks."

In session 13, David talks about a second difficult conversation with his wife, where she admitted she’s unsure if she’s happy in the marriage but didn’t fully commit to trying to work things out. David felt frustrated and hurt by her uncertainty, and while they remain civil, there is still a noticeable emotional distance between them. The therapist helps David process his feelings of helplessness and his growing recognition that things might not return to how they once were. They discuss the importance of shifting some focus back to David’s own needs and well-being, as he realizes that he’s lost sight of himself in the effort to fix the relationship. David decides to reconnect with an old hobby, working on his car, as a way to ground himself and regain a sense of joy outside of his roles as a husband and father. The therapist supports this shift toward self-care and encourages David to continue balancing his emotional work in the relationship with prioritizing his own well-being.
"Welcome back, David. Last week, you were preparing for another important conversation with your wife about where she stands in the relationship. How did it go?"

[sighs] "It was intense. I asked her how she really felt about the marriage, like we talked about. At first, she hesitated, but then she said she’s not sure if she’s happy anymore. She didn’t say she’s ready to leave, but she also didn’t commit to working on things either."
"That sounds like a heavy moment. What exactly did you ask, and how did you respond when she hesitated?"

"Well, I started by telling her that I’ve noticed she’s been distant for a while, and I asked her if she’s still invested in the relationship. She looked away at first, like she didn’t want to answer. I gave her a minute and asked again, but softer this time. I said, 'I really need to know how you’re feeling about us, even if it’s hard to talk about.' That’s when she finally said she’s unsure."
"And when she told you she’s unsure about her happiness, what did you say next?"

"I asked her what’s been making her feel that way, and she mentioned feeling overwhelmed with the kids and her job. She said that lately, she’s been questioning whether she’s happy, but she doesn’t know if it’s the marriage or just everything else in her life."
"It sounds like she’s feeling a lot of pressure in different areas, not just the marriage. How did you respond to her talking about her stress?"

"I told her I understood, but I asked her if she thought the marriage was part of what’s making her feel overwhelmed. She said she didn’t know and that she’s confused about everything right now. That’s when I started to feel like maybe there’s nothing I can do to fix this."
"I imagine that left you feeling pretty helpless. How did she react when you expressed your concern about not being able to fix things?"

"She didn’t say much at first. She just kind of nodded. Then I asked her if she even wants to try to make things better, and that’s when she said something that really hit me. She said, 'I don’t know if trying will change anything.' That was hard to hear."
"I can see why. That statement feels very uncertain, almost like she’s questioning whether it’s worth the effort. How did you handle hearing that from her?"

"I didn’t know what to say at first. I just sat there for a minute. Then I told her that I want to try, but I need to know if she’s willing to meet me halfway. She didn’t give me a clear answer. She just said she’s too tired to think about it right now."
"That must have been frustrating. She’s expressing exhaustion but not giving you the clarity you need. What did you do after that?"

"I didn’t want to push her, so I just told her we could talk about it later when she’s feeling up to it. I ended up walking out of the room because I didn’t want to say something I’d regret. It was a lot to take in."

"You handled that with a lot of restraint, especially considering the emotional weight of the conversation. It sounds like you were trying to give her space without completely walking away from the issue. How have things been between you two since then?"
"We’ve been civil, but distant. It’s like we’re just going through the motions. We haven’t talked about it again since that night."
"That distance can feel isolating, especially after such a heavy conversation. Do you think you’re both avoiding the topic for now, or is it more about giving each other time to process?"
"Probably a little of both. I don’t want to push her, but I also don’t want to just ignore it forever. It’s eating at me, but I don’t know if she’s ready to talk again."

"That makes sense. It’s important to strike a balance between giving her space and addressing the issue before it becomes even harder to talk about. What’s your gut feeling about when to bring it up again?"
"I think I should give it another week or so, but I don’t want to wait too long. I don’t want her to think I’m just giving up either."

"That sounds like a reasonable plan. Giving her some space while also preparing yourself for another conversation can help ensure that when you do talk again, it’s more constructive. How do you feel emotionally now that you’ve had a little time to reflect on what she said?"
"I’m still hurting, but I guess I feel a little more prepared for whatever happens. I can’t keep hoping she’ll just change overnight, but I also don’t want to lose hope completely."

"That’s a challenging balance—acknowledging the reality of the situation while still holding onto some hope. Do you think part of you is preparing for the possibility that the relationship might not be what it once was?"
"Yeah, I think I’ve been preparing for that for a while now. It’s just hard to admit to myself. I keep telling myself that things can get better, but deep down, I’m not sure anymore."

"It’s natural to feel conflicted. There’s a part of you that wants to hold onto what you had, but there’s also the recognition that things have changed. How do you feel about exploring what that shift means for you personally, aside from the relationship?"
[pauses] "I’ve been thinking about that a lot lately. I’ve been so focused on fixing the marriage that I haven’t really thought about what I need, outside of us. Maybe I need to figure that out."

"That sounds like a crucial step. Shifting some of the focus to yourself—your needs, your well-being—can help you gain clarity on what you want, both in the relationship and in your own life. What do you think would be the first step in doing that?"
"I think I need to start by figuring out what makes me happy again. I’ve been so wrapped up in being a husband and a father that I’ve forgotten about myself."

"That’s a powerful realization. Rediscovering what brings you joy outside of those roles could help you regain a sense of balance and fulfillment. What’s one small thing you could do this week to reconnect with that part of yourself?"
"I used to love working on my car. I haven’t touched it in months. Maybe I’ll spend some time in the garage this weekend, just to clear my head and do something I enjoy."

"That sounds like a great idea. Engaging in something that brings you joy and allows you to focus on yourself could be a helpful way to reset emotionally. How do you think you’ll feel after taking some time for yourself in that way?"
"I think it’ll help. I’ve been so drained that I haven’t had time to think about what I need. It’s probably long overdue."

"It’s definitely overdue, and it’s important that you’re recognizing that now. Taking time for yourself doesn’t mean you’re giving up on the relationship; it means you’re making sure you’re in a stronger place emotionally, no matter what happens."
"Yeah, I need that. I’ve been feeling like I’m losing myself in all of this. Maybe focusing on something I love will help me feel more grounded."

"Absolutely. Feeling grounded in yourself will make it easier to handle whatever comes next, whether it’s in your relationship or any other area of your life. How do you feel about continuing to explore this shift toward prioritizing yourself?"
"I think it’s what I need to do. I’ve been so focused on her and the kids that I’ve lost sight of myself. I need to change that."

"That’s a huge step, David. By shifting some of that focus back to yourself, you’re giving yourself the emotional support you need to move forward. We’ll keep exploring this balance as you continue to process everything that’s happening."
"Thanks. I feel like I’m starting to figure things out, even though it’s still hard."
"You’ve made incredible progress, even through the difficult moments. It’s okay to take things one step at a time, and we’ll keep working on this together."

In session 14, David discusses how working on his car provided a welcome distraction, but he couldn’t fully escape the underlying worries about his marriage. The therapist helps him recognize that his feelings of carrying the emotional burden in the relationship stem from his childhood, where he felt responsible for holding things together between his parents. They explore the possibility of David letting go of the role of being the 'fixer' and instead embracing vulnerability with his wife. Although he feels afraid of what might happen if he stops trying to hold everything together, David acknowledges that vulnerability might be the key to reconnecting with his wife. They end the session by focusing on a small step: David will share with his wife how emotionally drained he’s been, opening the door for more honest communication.
"Welcome back, David. Last session, we talked about shifting focus to your own well-being while giving your wife space. How did it go with finding time for yourself this week?"
"It went okay. I worked on my car like I planned, and it helped me clear my head. It felt good to focus on something other than the relationship for once."
"That’s great to hear. How did it feel, spending that time on something you enjoy, outside the pressures of the marriage?"

"It was relaxing, but there was still this underlying worry. Even when I was in the garage, I couldn’t fully shut out everything that’s going on with her. I kept wondering if she’s thinking about the same things or if she’s already checked out."

"It sounds like even in those moments of relaxation, the uncertainty of where things stand in your marriage is weighing on you. What thoughts or feelings come up when you imagine her being 'checked out' of the relationship?"

[pauses] "I guess it feels like a betrayal in a way. Not like she’s done something wrong, but it’s the idea that she might not care as much anymore. I’ve been putting in so much effort, and the thought of her emotionally distancing herself feels like she’s giving up."
"That feeling of emotional abandonment can be powerful. Does it remind you of any earlier experiences in your life where you felt left to carry a burden alone?"

[thinks for a moment] "Yeah, I guess it goes back to my parents. My dad was always at work, and my mom leaned on me a lot. I felt like I had to hold everything together, even when I was a kid. I didn’t have much of a choice."

"So there’s a pattern here—feeling like the weight of the relationship falls on you, just as it did when you were younger with your family. How do you think those early experiences shaped the way you approach your marriage now?"
"I think I’ve always felt like it’s my job to keep things together, no matter what. Even now, when things are falling apart, I feel like I need to fix it. It’s exhausting."

"That’s an important realization, David. It seems like that early role of being the one to 'hold things together' is still playing out now, and it’s leaving you feeling drained. How does it feel to recognize that connection?"
"It makes sense, but it’s hard to accept. I’ve been stuck in this pattern for so long that I don’t know how to break out of it."

"Recognizing the pattern is the first step toward breaking it. Sometimes, when we see how our past affects our present, it opens the door to making different choices. How do you feel about stepping back from that role of always being the fixer?"
"It feels strange, like I’m giving up or not doing my part. But I also know I can’t keep doing this by myself."

"That tension between feeling responsible and recognizing that you can’t carry it all alone is key here. What do you think would happen if you let go of the idea that it’s your job to fix everything?"
"I don’t know. Part of me feels like if I let go, everything will fall apart. But another part of me is relieved by the idea of not having to be the one holding it all together."

"That relief is telling. It suggests that part of you is ready to stop carrying this burden alone, even if it feels risky. What do you think would happen if you allowed yourself to sit with that relief a little more?"
[pauses] "I guess I’d feel lighter, but also more vulnerable. Like if I’m not the one keeping things together, what’s going to happen?"

"That sense of vulnerability can be difficult, especially when you’ve spent so much time protecting yourself by taking control. But vulnerability can also create space for growth and change. How do you feel about exploring that vulnerability in your marriage?"
"I’ve always been afraid of showing too much vulnerability. It’s like if I let my guard down, everything will fall apart. But I know I can’t keep this up forever."

"That fear of falling apart if you’re vulnerable ties into those early experiences with your parents. When you were younger, you didn’t have the option of letting things go. But now, you have more agency. How do you feel about the idea that being vulnerable might actually strengthen your relationship, rather than weaken it?"
[thinks for a moment] "It’s hard to believe that sometimes. I’ve always thought of vulnerability as weakness, like it’s something I can’t afford. But maybe it’s time to try something different."

"It sounds like part of you is ready to take that step, even though it’s unfamiliar. Vulnerability isn’t about being weak—it’s about being open and allowing yourself to be seen for who you are. How do you think your wife might respond if you started sharing more of your fears and feelings with her?"
"I think she might appreciate it, but I’m also scared she won’t care. What if she’s already too distant?"

"That fear of her being too distant is understandable, but it’s also important to remember that vulnerability can sometimes bridge that emotional gap. Even if she’s distant now, sharing your feelings might help create a path back to connection. How do you feel about trying that, step by step?"
"I think I can try. It’s not easy for me, but I know I need to do something different. We can’t keep going like this."

"That’s a brave step, David. It’s not about changing everything overnight, but allowing yourself to share small pieces of what you’re feeling. What’s one thing you could tell her this week that shows some of that vulnerability?"
[pauses] "Maybe I could tell her how tired I’ve been. Not just physically, but emotionally. I’ve been holding so much in, and I think it’s time I let her know."

"That sounds like an important starting point. Letting her know how emotionally drained you’ve been could open up a conversation about where you both stand and what needs to change. How do you feel about that?"
"It feels scary, but also necessary. I need to stop pretending like I have it all together because I don’t."

"That’s a powerful realization. By letting go of the facade of 'having it all together,' you’re creating space for honesty and connection. How do you plan to take care of yourself emotionally as you move into this more vulnerable space?"
"I think I’ll keep doing what I’ve been doing—taking walks, working on my car. I need those breaks to clear my head."

"That’s a good plan. Taking time for yourself while also stepping into this new space of vulnerability will help you manage the emotional weight of it. How do you feel about balancing both—being open with her while still prioritizing your own self-care?"
"I think it’s the only way forward. If I don’t take care of myself, I won’t have the energy to keep going in the relationship."

"That’s exactly right. It’s about creating balance—being open with her, but also making sure you’re not losing yourself in the process. We’ll keep working on that balance together. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"
"I feel better, like I’ve got a plan. It’s going to be hard, but I’m ready to try being more open with her."
"That’s a big step, and you’ve made a lot of progress in getting to this point. We’ll continue building on this in our next session. You’re not alone in this process."

In session 15, the therapist shifts the conversation toward David’s relationship with his kids. David opens up about how the tension between him and his wife has affected his relationship with his children, particularly his oldest son, Jake, who has become more distant. David expresses guilt for not being as present as he wants to be due to the emotional stress he’s under. They discuss small, intentional actions he can take to reconnect with his children, such as spending more time reading to his daughter Lily and playing with Jake. The therapist encourages David to focus on these meaningful moments with his kids to help reduce the pressure he feels and to regain a sense of stability in his family life. David leaves the session feeling more hopeful about reconnecting with his children, even though his marriage remains unresolved.

"Welcome back, David. We’ve been focusing a lot on your relationship with your wife, and I know that’s been weighing heavily on you. But I’ve been thinking—we haven’t talked much about your relationship with your kids. How are things with them?"
[sighs] "Yeah, I guess we haven’t really talked about that much. It’s been… complicated. I love them, of course, but with everything going on, it’s hard to be the dad I want to be."
"What do you mean by 'complicated'? Can you tell me more about what your relationship with them is like right now?"

"Well, my oldest, Jake, he’s 6. He’s smart, but I can tell he senses something’s off between me and my wife. He’s been asking more questions lately, like 'Why are you and Mommy not happy?' I don’t really know how to answer him."
"That sounds tough. How do you usually respond when Jake asks about the tension between you and your wife?"
"I usually tell him that Mommy and Daddy are just tired, that we’ve been busy with work and the kids. I don’t want to lie to him, but I also don’t want to drag him into the mess."
"It sounds like you’re trying to protect him from the situation. Do you think he’s picking up on more than just tiredness?"
"Yeah, I’m sure he is. He’s always been perceptive, even for his age. He knows something’s wrong, but I don’t know how much to tell him. I don’t want him to worry."

"That’s understandable. You don’t want him to feel the burden of the conflict between you and your wife, but he’s clearly sensing something. How do you think he’s been affected by what’s going on between you two?"

[pauses] "I think he’s more anxious. He’s been having trouble sleeping, and sometimes he gets frustrated easily, like when things don’t go his way. I’m starting to wonder if it’s because of the tension at home."
"That’s definitely possible. Kids, especially at his age, are very sensitive to the emotional atmosphere around them. Have you noticed any changes in how he interacts with you or your wife?"
"He’s been more distant with me lately. I don’t know if it’s because I’m distracted or what, but we used to play together more. Now, he seems to prefer spending time with his mom."
"How does that make you feel, knowing that Jake’s been a little distant with you?"
"It hurts, honestly. I feel like I’m losing him, like he doesn’t see me as the fun dad anymore. I don’t blame him, though. I haven’t been around as much, mentally at least."
"That emotional distance can be hard, especially when you feel like you’re losing your connection with him. Do you think part of the distance is related to the tension between you and your wife?"
"Yeah, probably. He’s been spending more time with her lately, and I think he senses that I’m stressed. I try to put on a happy face, but kids are smarter than we give them credit for."
"They really are. Jake’s picking up on your stress, even if you’re not explicitly showing it. What about your other kids? How are things with them?"

"Well, my middle one, Lily, she’s 3. She’s more carefree, but she’s been clingier with my wife lately too. I think she notices when we’re not talking, but she’s too young to really understand what’s going on."
"It sounds like Lily might not fully understand the conflict, but she can still sense the emotional atmosphere. How does she interact with you?"

"She’s still affectionate with me, but I’ve noticed she clings to her mom more. She used to run to me when I got home from work, but now it’s like she wants to stay close to my wife all the time. It’s like she feels safer with her."
"That’s interesting. It seems like Lily is picking up on the tension as well, even if she can’t fully understand it. How do you feel about her becoming more attached to your wife during this time?"

"It makes sense, I guess. My wife has been spending more time with her, and I’ve been preoccupied with everything going on. But it still stings a bit, you know? I feel like I’m not as close to her as I used to be."

"That makes sense, David. It’s natural to feel hurt when you notice that distance, especially since you’re going through so much emotionally yourself. How does that affect the way you interact with her?"
"I try not to let it show, but sometimes I feel disconnected. I don’t want to push her away, but it’s hard to be fully present when I’m so stressed about everything else."
"That disconnection can be challenging, especially when you’re already feeling emotionally drained. Do you think there’s a way to rebuild some of that connection with Lily, even in small ways?"

"I think so. She loves when I read to her at night, so maybe I can start doing that more. I haven’t been as consistent with bedtime lately because I’ve been so tired, but I think she’d like it if I made more time for that."

"That sounds like a great idea. Small, consistent moments like reading at bedtime could help re-establish that connection with her. What about your youngest? How’s your relationship with your 1-year-old?"

[smiling slightly] "Oh, Emily… She’s too young to really notice anything, I think. She’s still in that stage where she just needs us for the basics. But even with her, I sometimes feel like I’m not as present as I should be."
"It’s understandable that you might feel distant, given everything you’re dealing with. Even though Emily is still young, those early bonds are important. How do you feel when you’re with her?"
"Honestly, it’s a mix. I love spending time with her, but there’s this part of me that feels guilty, like I’m not giving her the same attention that Jake and Lily got when they were her age."
"That guilt is something we can explore. Do you feel like you’re carrying the pressure of being the 'perfect' father with all three of your kids, especially given the challenges in your marriage?"

"Yeah, I do. I feel like I’m failing them sometimes. Like I should be more engaged, more present, but there’s always something pulling me away—whether it’s work, stress, or my relationship with my wife."

"It sounds like you’re holding yourself to a very high standard. Parenting, especially under stressful circumstances, is never easy. How do you think the pressure you put on yourself is affecting your ability to connect with your kids?"

"I think it’s making it worse. The more I feel like I’m failing, the more I withdraw. It’s like this cycle where I pull back because I’m stressed, but then I feel guilty for not being there, and that makes me pull back even more."

"That’s a powerful insight, David. Recognizing that cycle is important because it shows how guilt and stress can feed into each other. How do you think we can break that cycle, starting with small steps?"

[thinks for a moment] "Maybe I can start by just being more intentional with my time. Like making sure I’m present during those small moments—reading to Lily, playing with Jake, even just holding Emily when I get home."

"That’s a good plan. It’s about quality, not necessarily quantity. By focusing on those small moments of connection, you can start to rebuild that emotional closeness without overwhelming yourself. How do you feel about that?"
"It feels doable. I think I’ve been putting too much pressure on myself to be everything to everyone, and that’s just not realistic."
"Exactly. You don’t have to be perfect; you just need to be present in the ways that matter. How do you think your kids will respond if you start making these small changes?"

"I think they’ll notice. Even with Jake, if I spend more time with him, maybe he won’t feel like I’m so distant. I’m sure Lily will love having more bedtime stories, and with Emily… I think it’ll help me bond with her more."
"That sounds like a positive direction. How do you feel emotionally about reconnecting with your kids in this way?"

[sighs] "Honestly, it feels good to have a plan. I’ve been so caught up in my issues with my wife that I haven’t focused on my kids as much as I should. It feels good to be moving in the right direction."

"It’s important to acknowledge the progress you’re making, David. Even though the situation with your wife is difficult, you’re taking steps to strengthen your relationship with your kids. How does that impact the way you think about your role in the family overall?"

"It makes me feel more hopeful. I’ve been feeling like everything’s falling apart, but maybe if I focus on my kids, I can find some stability again. I don’t want them to grow up with the same tension I did."

"That’s a powerful goal—to create a different environment for your kids than the one you experienced growing up. It’s clear that you care deeply about their well-being, and by focusing on those connections, you’re building a foundation for them. How do you think this will influence your approach to your marriage?"

"I think it’ll take some of the pressure off. If I’m not so focused on fixing everything with my wife, maybe I can just be a better dad. And maybe that’ll help me feel more grounded when it comes to dealing with the marriage."

"That sounds like a healthy shift. By focusing on what you can control—your relationship with your kids—you’re creating emotional stability for yourself, which can also help in how you approach your wife. How do you feel about continuing to explore that balance in future sessions?"
"I think it’s important. I’ve been too focused on the wrong things, and it’s time to start focusing on what matters more—my kids and myself."

"That’s a great realization, David. We’ll continue working on this balance between your role as a father and your emotional well-being, while also addressing your marriage at a pace that feels manageable. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"
"I feel more at peace. I’m not saying everything’s fixed, but I feel like I’m not so stuck in this cycle anymore."
"That’s progress. One step at a time, and we’ll keep building on that. You’ve made great strides in understanding what you need and what your family needs from you."

In session 16, David reports that the changes he’s made with his children have had a positive impact. He’s been more present with them, especially with Jake, and feels less guilty as a father. The therapist acknowledges David’s progress with his children and shifts the conversation to his wife. David feels stuck in a 'holding pattern' with her, where they aren’t fighting but aren’t addressing the deeper issues in their relationship either. He expresses fear about bringing up a conversation about where they both stand, worried about what she might say. The therapist helps David consider starting the conversation in a gentle, non-confrontational way, focusing on her feelings without diving into the heavier topics immediately. David feels ready to take this next step, bolstered by the emotional grounding he’s gained through reconnecting with his kids.
"Welcome back, David. Last session, we talked about reconnecting with your kids and focusing on small moments of presence with them. How has that been going?"
"It’s been going better than I expected, actually. I’ve been making more time for the kids, and I can see a difference. Jake, especially—he seems more relaxed around me."
"That’s great to hear. What have you been doing with Jake that’s helped him relax around you?"

"We’ve been playing more. He loves building with his Legos, so I’ve been joining him for that. We used to do it all the time, but I’ve been so distracted lately. Now, it’s like we’ve found our thing again."
"That must feel rewarding, reconnecting with him in that way. How did it feel for you when you noticed the change in him?"

[smiles] "It felt good. For the first time in a while, I didn’t feel like I was failing as a dad. He even started talking to me more, asking questions about the things I used to do as a kid. It reminded me of how much I’ve missed out on lately."
"It sounds like you’ve opened a new door with Jake, creating space for more meaningful interactions. Have you noticed any shifts in your relationship with Lily and Emily?"

"With Lily, yeah. I’ve been reading to her more, like we talked about. She looks forward to it now—she’ll bring me a book and climb onto my lap. I can tell she’s feeling more secure. Emily’s still so young, but I’ve been holding her more when I get home from work. She’s always giggling now when I walk in."
"It sounds like you’re building stronger bonds with all of them. How has this shift impacted the way you see yourself as a father?"

"I guess I don’t feel as guilty anymore. Before, I felt like I was failing them because I wasn’t there mentally, but now that I’m making time for them, I feel like I’m doing better. It’s still hard balancing everything, but at least I know I’m trying."

"That’s a significant shift, David. Recognizing that you’re doing your best and that being present is what matters most is an important step. How has this change with your kids impacted your stress levels overall?"
"I feel lighter. I think I was carrying a lot of guilt about not being there for them. Now that I’m more involved, I feel like a better dad, and that takes some of the pressure off."
"That’s great progress. Releasing some of that guilt seems to have freed up emotional energy for you. How has your wife responded to the changes you’ve made with the kids?"
[pauses] "She’s noticed, I think. She hasn’t said much, but I can tell she’s watching. We’re still not really talking about us, though."

"It’s interesting that she’s observing, but not engaging much yet. How do you feel about the fact that things between you and her are still unresolved, even as you’ve been making progress with the kids?"
"It’s frustrating. I feel like I’m making strides with the kids, but with her… it’s like we’re in a holding pattern. We haven’t fought, but we haven’t really talked about anything important either."
"That holding pattern must feel uncomfortable, especially since you’re putting effort into other areas of your life. Do you think there’s a reason you two haven’t been addressing the deeper issues?"
"I think we’re both avoiding it. I don’t want to push her, and maybe she doesn’t want to push me either. We’re civil, but there’s this big thing between us that we’re not dealing with."

"Avoiding the conflict can sometimes feel easier in the short term, but it often builds tension underneath. What do you think would happen if you tried to open up a conversation with her about where you both stand?"
"I don’t know. Part of me feels like we need to talk, but another part of me is scared. What if she says she’s done? I’ve been putting in the effort, but I still don’t know where her head is at."

"That fear is understandable. You’ve been working hard to improve things, especially with the kids, and the uncertainty about her feelings must be weighing on you. What do you think is holding you back from starting that conversation?"
"I think it’s the fear of hearing something I don’t want to hear. I’m not sure I’m ready for that yet."

"That fear makes sense, but it’s also keeping you in this place of uncertainty. How do you feel about the possibility of starting small—asking her about her feelings, without diving into the bigger issues right away?"
"Maybe. I think I could ask her how she’s feeling in general, without putting too much pressure on it. That way, it doesn’t feel like a confrontation."

"That sounds like a manageable step. Opening up the conversation in a way that feels safe for both of you might help ease some of the tension. How do you think she’ll respond if you approach it gently like that?"
"I think she’ll talk if I don’t make it too heavy. She’s been stressed too, and I don’t want to make her feel cornered."

"It sounds like you’re attuned to her needs, and that’s important. By approaching it with care, you’re showing her that you’re open to hearing her feelings without adding pressure. How do you feel about taking that step this week?"
"I’ll try. I think it’s time to at least get a sense of where her head is at. I don’t want to stay stuck like this forever."

"That’s a good approach. Even just opening the door to conversation could help you both move forward, whether that’s toward resolution or understanding where you each stand. How do you feel about managing your own emotions during that conversation?"

[pauses] "It’s going to be hard, but I think I can handle it. I’ve been doing better with the kids, and that’s helped me feel more grounded. If it doesn’t go the way I hope, at least I know I’m trying."

"That emotional grounding is going to be key. You’ve been putting in the work with your kids, and that’s given you a solid foundation to stand on. No matter how the conversation goes, you’re showing up as your best self. How do you feel about continuing to prioritize your own well-being while navigating this with your wife?"
"It’s important. I’ve realized that I can’t lose myself in this anymore. I need to be there for my kids and myself, no matter what happens with her."

"That’s a big shift, David. By focusing on your own well-being, you’re also creating space for your relationship to either heal or change in a way that’s healthier for both of you. How are you feeling about the progress you’ve made so far?"
"I feel better, more in control of myself. It’s still hard with my wife, but I’m not as overwhelmed as I was before. I think focusing on the kids has helped me stay grounded."

"It sounds like you’ve made significant progress in finding balance, both as a father and in taking care of yourself emotionally. We’ll continue working on that balance in future sessions, especially as you navigate the upcoming conversation with your wife. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"
"I feel ready to take the next step. I know it’s going to be hard, but I’m not as scared as I was before. I think I can handle it."
"That’s great to hear. You’ve come a long way, and we’ll keep building on this progress. Remember, it’s about taking it one step at a time, and you’re doing just that."

In session 17, David discusses a recent conversation with his wife about their emotional state. His wife admitted that she’s emotionally tired and uncertain if things will get better, which was hard for David to hear but not surprising. David shared his own feelings of emotional exhaustion, and for the first time, they seemed to be on the same page, acknowledging their struggles without trying to fix them immediately. The therapist helps David process this conversation, recognizing that being open about his feelings created space for his wife to feel less pressure. They discuss the importance of maintaining emotional alignment without rushing into decisions, and David feels more at peace knowing that they are both sitting with the uncertainty. The session ends with a focus on continuing to prioritize his emotional well-being and his connection with his children.
"Welcome back, David. Last week, you were preparing to have an important conversation with your wife about her feelings. How did it go?"

[sighs] "It was hard, but I did it. I asked her how she’s been feeling, and at first, she didn’t want to talk. But I stayed calm and asked her to be honest with me. She said she’s feeling tired—emotionally tired—and she’s not sure if things will get better."
"That sounds like a difficult conversation. How did it feel for you to hear her say she’s emotionally tired and uncertain?"
"It hurt, but at the same time, it wasn’t surprising. I think I’ve known for a while that she’s been feeling this way, but hearing her say it out loud made it real."
"It sounds like you’ve been sensing her distance for a while. How did the conversation continue after she shared that with you?"
"I told her I’ve been feeling the same way. I said I’ve been tired too, and that I don’t know how to fix things either. I was honest with her. I didn’t try to act like I had all the answers."
"That’s a big step—being honest with her about your own feelings, without trying to fix things right away. How did she respond when you opened up like that?"

"She was quiet for a while, but then she said she appreciated that I wasn’t trying to fix everything. I think she’s been feeling overwhelmed by the pressure to make things work, and me being honest about my own struggles seemed to take some of that pressure off."
"That’s an important shift. By being vulnerable and sharing your own uncertainty, you created space for her to feel less pressure. How did you feel after that part of the conversation?"

"Relieved, actually. It felt like we were on the same page for once, instead of me trying to solve everything while she’s pulling away. We didn’t come to any conclusions, but it felt like a step forward."
"It sounds like the conversation helped create some emotional alignment between you two, even if there wasn’t a resolution. Did you talk about where things might go from here?"

"Not really. We didn’t talk about the future or what we’re going to do next. It was more about acknowledging where we are right now—that we’re both tired and not sure what to do. I think we’re both scared to make any big decisions."

"That makes sense. Acknowledging where you both are emotionally is an important first step. Even though it’s uncertain, it sounds like you’re both open to sitting with that uncertainty for now. How do you feel about that?"
"I’m okay with it for now. I think trying to force a solution would make things worse. We’re both still processing everything, and I don’t want to rush into any decisions."

"It’s wise to give yourselves time to process. Sometimes, staying in that space of uncertainty allows for more clarity to emerge over time. How do you feel about continuing to focus on your own emotional well-being while you and your wife navigate this?"
"I think it’s important. I’ve been doing better with the kids, and that’s helped me feel more grounded. I need to keep focusing on myself and the kids, no matter what happens with the marriage."

"That’s a healthy perspective. You’re creating emotional stability for yourself and your children, which will help you navigate the uncertainty with your wife. How has your relationship with the kids been this past week?"

"It’s been good. I’ve been spending more time with Jake and Lily. Jake’s been asking me to play Legos with him almost every day now, and Lily’s been bringing me books every night. I think they’re starting to feel more secure."
"That’s wonderful to hear. It sounds like your consistent presence is making a big difference for them. How do you feel about the changes you’ve seen in your relationship with them?"
"It feels good. I feel like I’m getting closer to them, and that’s helped me feel more at peace, even with everything else going on."
"That’s significant progress, David. Rebuilding those connections with your kids is a source of emotional strength for you. How has your youngest, Emily, been responding to the changes?"
[smiling] "Emily’s always happy to see me when I get home. She’s still so young, but I’ve been holding her more and just spending quiet time with her. It’s been nice."
"That’s beautiful. Even though she’s young, those quiet moments are important for both of you. How do you think these positive changes with your kids have affected your emotional state overall?"
"I think it’s made me feel more balanced. I’m not as focused on the stress with my wife because I’m spending more time being present with the kids. It’s like I have something positive to hold onto."

"That balance is crucial. By focusing on the parts of your life where you can create connection and stability, you’re building emotional resilience. How do you feel about maintaining that balance as you and your wife continue to navigate your relationship?"

"I think it’s helping me stay grounded. Even though things with my wife are still uncertain, being present with the kids gives me something to hold onto. It’s like, even if the marriage doesn’t work out, I still have them, and I can be a good father to them."

"That’s a powerful realization, David. Knowing that you have a solid relationship with your children, regardless of what happens with your marriage, can provide a strong emotional foundation. How do you think this new sense of balance will affect how you approach your conversations with your wife moving forward?"

"I think it’ll help me stay calm. Before, I was so focused on trying to fix the marriage that I was losing myself in it. Now, I feel like I have more control over my emotions. I’m not as desperate, if that makes sense."

"That makes perfect sense. You’re no longer putting all of your emotional energy into trying to fix the marriage, and that’s giving you the emotional space to handle these conversations with more clarity and less pressure. How do you feel about the idea of continuing to approach your wife with that same calmness and openness?"

"I think it’s the only way forward. If I push too hard, she’ll pull away even more. But if I’m patient and calm, maybe she’ll feel more comfortable opening up. I just don’t know how long I can keep waiting."

"That uncertainty can be difficult, especially when you’re ready to move forward but unsure of her willingness. How do you plan to take care of yourself emotionally while you’re waiting for her to be ready to engage more deeply?"
"I think I’ll keep focusing on the kids and on myself. I’ve started running again in the mornings, just to clear my head. It helps me stay grounded, and I think it’s making me a better father too."

"That’s a great way to take care of yourself, physically and emotionally. Engaging in activities that give you a sense of calm and clarity will help you maintain that balance you’ve been working toward. How do you feel about continuing to explore these self-care practices?"

"I think it’s important. I can’t let myself fall back into that place where all I’m thinking about is the marriage. I need to stay focused on what I can control—my relationship with the kids and my own well-being."

"Exactly. By focusing on what you can control, you’re creating a sense of stability for yourself and your family. How do you feel about the possibility that your wife might not be ready to engage with the relationship the way you hope she will?"
"That’s the hard part. I’ve been trying to prepare myself for that, but it’s tough. I know there’s a chance that she won’t want to keep working on things, but I don’t want to give up hope just yet."

"It’s natural to want to hold onto hope, especially when you’ve been putting in so much effort. How do you think you’ll manage your emotions if she does decide that she’s no longer invested in the relationship?"
[pauses] "I don’t know. I guess I’d have to accept it, but I’m not sure I’m ready for that yet. I’ve been doing better, but the thought of losing the marriage still scares me."

"That fear is understandable, David. It’s a big unknown, and it’s okay to feel scared. How do you think you’ll navigate that fear while still staying open to whatever outcome comes from your conversations with her?"

"I think I’ll just have to take it one step at a time. I can’t let myself get too far ahead, thinking about the worst-case scenario. I’ll focus on what’s in front of me right now—being a good dad and taking care of myself."

"That’s a healthy approach. By staying present and focusing on what you can control, you’re giving yourself the emotional tools to handle whatever comes next. How do you feel about continuing to approach your relationship with your wife with patience, even if it takes time to get clarity?"
"I think I can do that, at least for now. I just hope that we can have more honest conversations like we did last time. It felt good to be on the same page, even if just for a little while."

"That’s an important goal—to have more honest, open conversations. Each time you communicate with that level of honesty, you’re moving toward greater clarity, whether it’s about staying together or deciding to part ways. How do you feel about continuing to engage with her in that way?"
"I think it’s the only way we’ll ever figure out what’s next. I can’t keep pretending like everything’s fine, and neither can she. We need to talk, even if it’s hard."

"That honesty is crucial. By committing to those difficult conversations, you’re creating space for both of you to figure out what you truly want. How are you feeling emotionally about the possibility of those conversations leading to a difficult decision?"
[pauses] "I’m not sure I’m ready for that yet. I want to keep trying, but I also know we can’t keep going like this forever. It’s scary, but I think I have to be open to whatever happens."

"That’s a brave perspective, David. Acknowledging that fear while staying open to whatever comes next is a big step. How do you feel about continuing to focus on your emotional growth, regardless of the outcome with your wife?"

"I think it’s the only way forward. I’ve been so focused on the marriage for so long that I forgot about myself. Now that I’m taking care of myself and the kids, I feel more grounded. No matter what happens, I need to keep that going."

"That’s a powerful realization. By focusing on your own emotional growth, you’re not only supporting yourself but also creating a stronger foundation for your family. How do you feel about continuing this process of growth and self-care in our future sessions?"
"I feel good about it. It’s been helping, and I think it’s the only way I’ll get through this—whether we stay together or not."

"You’ve made incredible progress, David. We’ll keep building on that emotional growth, and we’ll continue exploring how to navigate your relationship with your wife while staying true to yourself. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"
"I feel more at peace. I’m still nervous about the future, but I’m not as overwhelmed. I think I can handle whatever comes next."
"That’s a great place to be—finding peace in the midst of uncertainty. We’ll keep working on that balance and continue to support your emotional well-being moving forward."

In session 18, David reports that while things with his wife remain stable, there has been no further deep conversation, leaving him feeling stuck in limbo. The therapist suggests the possibility of taking a break or vacation, not just to give his wife space, but to allow David time to recharge and reflect. They discuss how time apart could provide both of them with clarity about their emotional connection, and whether they miss each other or feel relieved by the space. David expresses nervousness about the potential outcomes, particularly the fear that his wife might not miss him, but recognizes that it’s better to know than to remain in uncertainty. The therapist helps David explore the idea of taking a trip to a quiet, peaceful place where he can focus on himself, and David agrees to start making plans for the break. The session ends with David feeling a mix of nervousness and relief, acknowledging that taking time for himself is a necessary step in gaining clarity about his marriage.

"Welcome back, David. Last time we talked, you were finding some balance between focusing on the kids and yourself, while also managing the uncertainty with your wife. How has this past week been for you?"

"It’s been okay. I’ve been trying to stay consistent with the kids, and that’s still going well. With my wife… well, we haven’t really had another deep conversation since that one, but things have been stable."
"Stable, but not necessarily moving forward?"
"Yeah, exactly. It’s like we’re just coexisting right now. We’re not fighting, but we’re not really talking about anything important either."
"That sounds like a tough place to be—where nothing is actively wrong, but nothing is improving either. How does it feel for you, being in that space of limbo?"
[sighs] "It’s frustrating. I know we need to talk more, but part of me is afraid to push too hard. I don’t want to make things worse, but at the same time, I’m tired of waiting."
"That’s understandable, David. It can be exhausting to feel stuck, especially when you’ve been putting in effort. Have you had any thoughts about how to break through this stagnation?"
"I’ve thought about it a lot, but I don’t know what the next step should be. I don’t want to push her, but I also don’t want to keep waiting for something to happen."

"It’s a delicate balance, isn’t it? One thing that comes to mind is the idea of taking a step back—not just emotionally, but physically. I wonder how some space, both for you and your wife, might help give both of you clarity. Have you considered taking a break—maybe even going on a vacation?"
"A vacation? I mean, I hadn’t really thought about it. Do you think that would help?"

"I think it could. A vacation would give you time to recharge and reflect, but it would also give your wife some space to feel your absence. Sometimes being apart helps people realize what they miss—or, in some cases, what they don’t. It could be an important way for both of you to gain some clarity."
[pauses] "I hadn’t thought about it that way. You think if I’m away for a while, it might make her realize something?"

"It’s possible. If she feels homesick for you and misses your presence, that could indicate that she’s still emotionally connected. On the other hand, if she feels more relieved during your absence, it might offer both of you insight into how she’s really feeling. Either way, it could help both of you see the relationship from a different perspective."
"How long are we talking? A few days wouldn’t really do anything, would it?"

"I’d suggest a bit longer—maybe 2 to 3 weeks. That gives enough time for both of you to experience what life is like without each other’s immediate presence. It’s long enough for feelings to surface, whether that’s longing or something else."
"2 to 3 weeks, huh? That’s a lot of time. I’ve never been away from the kids that long."

"I know it might feel difficult, especially since you’ve been working hard to reconnect with them. But you could also see it as a way to step back and recharge. This time away could help you be an even more present father when you return, not to mention give you the space to reflect on your marriage."
[pauses] "I guess it could work. It’s scary, though. What if I go and come back, and she doesn’t miss me at all? What if she feels better without me around?"

"That’s a valid fear, David. But it’s also important to remember that avoiding that possibility won’t change the reality of the situation. If she does feel more relief than homesickness, it’s better to know that now so you can decide how to move forward. Facing that truth, no matter how hard it is, can help both of you."
"Yeah, you’re right. It’s better to know. But still, I’m not sure I’m ready for that answer if it’s the one I don’t want."

"It’s natural to feel apprehensive, but giving both of you space could lead to clarity, no matter what that clarity reveals. And remember, the time away isn’t just for her—it’s for you too. You deserve time to reflect and think about what you need, not just what you want from her."
"That’s true. I guess I’ve been so focused on what she wants or needs that I haven’t really thought about myself much."
"Exactly. This could be an opportunity to center yourself and figure out what you want, independent of the marriage. Do you think you’d feel more clearheaded after taking some time away?"
"Maybe. I haven’t had time to myself in a long time. Between the kids, work, and everything with my wife, I’ve been pretty overwhelmed. A break might help."
"It sounds like it could be exactly what you need. Where would you go if you took this break?"
"I don’t know. Maybe somewhere quiet. I’ve always liked the mountains. A cabin, maybe. Just somewhere peaceful, away from everything."

"That sounds like a great idea—a place where you can disconnect from the daily stresses and just focus on yourself for a while. How do you feel about discussing this with your wife? Letting her know you’re considering taking some time away to think?"
"I think I can do that. It wouldn’t be easy, but I’d tell her that it’s not just about the marriage—it’s about me needing time to clear my head too. Do you think she’d be okay with it?"

"It’s hard to say how she’ll react, but approaching it from a place of honesty and calm, as you have been, will help. Letting her know it’s a way to take care of yourself, rather than just a way to escape, might help her understand."
"Yeah, I can see that. I’ll talk to her about it and see how she reacts."

"Good. And no matter how she responds, this is about taking care of you. You’ve been carrying a lot, and you deserve some time to focus on yourself. How do you feel about planning the trip and preparing for this break?"
"It feels strange, but I think it could help. I’ve been stuck in the same routine for so long that I haven’t had space to think clearly. Maybe being away for a while will give me some perspective."

"Perspective is exactly what a break like this can offer. It’s not just a vacation—it’s a chance to reassess what you need and how you feel. How are you feeling about the possibility of returning home after the break and seeing what has or hasn’t changed with your wife?"
"It’s nerve-wracking, to be honest. I’m afraid of coming back and finding that she didn’t miss me at all. But like you said, it’s better to know than to keep wondering."

"That’s right. And remember, it’s not just about what she feels—it’s also about how you feel after some time apart. Sometimes distance can help you see things more clearly too. You might come back with a new perspective on what you need from this relationship."
"I hope so. It’s scary, but I think it’s worth trying. I need to know where we stand, and I need a break from all of this stress."
"That’s a brave step, David. Taking time for yourself shows a lot of strength and self-awareness. How do you feel about starting to make plans for this trip?"
"I think I’ll start looking at places this week. I’m not sure exactly when I’ll go, but I want to have something lined up soon."

"That sounds like a good plan. Take your time and find a place that feels right for you. Once you’ve made some decisions, we can talk more about how to prepare emotionally for the break. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"
"I feel a little nervous, but also relieved. Just talking about the possibility of a break makes me feel lighter."
"That’s a good sign that this might be exactly what you need. We’ll keep discussing it as you make your plans, and we’ll support you through the process. You’re doing important work, David."

In session 19, David shares that he discussed the idea of taking a vacation with his wife, and she agreed it might be a good idea for both of them to have some space. While her neutral reaction left David feeling uncertain about whether she would miss him, he feels that the break is necessary. The therapist helps David explore the idea that the space might offer clarity for both of them, whether it brings them closer or reveals that their emotional connection has weakened. David has found a quiet cabin in the mountains and plans to spend the time reflecting on what he wants from the relationship, as well as focusing on self-care. The therapist emphasizes the importance of this break as a time for David to gain perspective, both on his marriage and on his own emotional needs.
"Welcome back, David. Last time we talked about the possibility of taking a vacation to give both you and your wife some space to reflect on the relationship. How did the conversation with her go?"

"It went better than I expected, actually. I told her I needed some time to clear my head, and that it wasn’t just about the marriage—it was about me needing a break too. She didn’t seem upset. In fact, she agreed it might be good for both of us."
"That’s a positive response. How did it feel to hear her agree with the idea of you taking some time away?"

[pauses] "Honestly, it was a relief, but also a little scary. Part of me was hoping she’d say she didn’t want me to go, that she’d miss me too much. But she seemed okay with it, which made me wonder if she’ll even notice I’m gone."
"It sounds like her calm reaction left you feeling a bit uncertain. What was the rest of the conversation like?"
"We talked a bit more, and she said it might be good for us to have some space. She didn’t say much else about her feelings, but she didn’t argue or push back. It was almost… neutral."
"Neutral can sometimes feel unsettling, especially when you’re hoping for a stronger reaction. Do you think her neutrality might be a reflection of her own emotional fatigue?"
"Maybe. She’s been pretty drained too, so it could just be that she’s as tired as I am. But part of me wonders if she’s relieved that I’m going away."
"That’s a valid concern, and it’s something we can keep exploring as you prepare for this break. How are you feeling about taking the trip now that she’s on board with it?"

"I’m still nervous, but I think it’s the right thing to do. I’ve been looking at some places in the mountains, and I found a cabin that seems perfect. It’s quiet, isolated, and just what I need to clear my head."

"That sounds like a good choice. A peaceful, quiet environment can give you the space to reflect without the usual distractions. How do you think this time away will help you process what’s happening in your marriage?"

"I think it’ll give me some perspective. Being in the same house with her all the time makes it hard to see things clearly. When I’m away, I’ll have time to think about what I really want and whether this marriage is still what I need."
"That’s a powerful intention for the trip—using the space to gain clarity on what you need moving forward. What do you hope to achieve emotionally during the time away?"

"I hope to get some peace of mind. I’ve been so consumed by the stress of the marriage that I haven’t had time to just think about myself. I want to come back with a clearer sense of what I want, not just what I think I should do for her or the kids."

"That’s an important shift—focusing on your own needs and desires, independent of the pressures of the marriage. How do you feel about the possibility that this time away might change how you view the relationship?"
[pauses] "That’s the scary part. What if I come back and realize that I don’t want to stay? Or worse, what if I come back and she doesn’t miss me at all?"

"Those are tough possibilities to consider, but it’s important to face them. By stepping away, you’re allowing yourself the chance to see the relationship from a distance, and that clarity—no matter what it reveals—will help you move forward. How do you think you’ll handle it emotionally if you do come back and feel like things haven’t changed?"

"I’m trying to prepare myself for that. I don’t want to come back with unrealistic expectations. If nothing changes, at least I’ll know where I stand, and maybe that’ll help me make a decision one way or the other."

"That’s a healthy approach, David. This break isn’t about forcing change, but about gaining insight—both into how you feel and how she feels in your absence. How do you plan to take care of yourself emotionally during the trip?"

"I’m going to focus on relaxing, doing things I enjoy. I haven’t been hiking in a while, so I’m planning to spend a lot of time outdoors. I’ll bring some books too—things that have nothing to do with work or the marriage. I just need to unwind."

"That sounds like a great way to recharge. Giving yourself time to disconnect from the daily stress and reconnect with activities that bring you joy can help you return with a clearer mind. How do you think your relationship with your kids will be affected by your time away?"
"That’s the hardest part. I’ve been spending more time with them, and I don’t want them to feel like I’m abandoning them. But I think if I explain it to them as a short trip, they’ll understand."

"It’s important to be honest with them, even at their young ages. Letting them know that you’re going away for a little while but that you’ll be back can help them feel secure. How do you plan to explain it to them?"

"I’ll tell Jake that Daddy needs a little break to clear his head. He’s old enough to understand that. Lily might need more reassurance, but I’ll tell her I’ll be back soon. Emily’s too young to really get it, but I’ll make sure they all know it’s not a big deal."

"That sounds like a thoughtful approach. By framing it as a break, you’re helping them feel safe while also modeling healthy self-care. How do you feel emotionally about being away from them for a few weeks?"
"I’ll miss them for sure, but I think it’ll be good for me. I need this time, and I know they’ll be okay with their mom while I’m gone."

"It’s great that you’re feeling confident about this step. Having that assurance about your kids can help you focus on yourself during the trip. How do you feel about balancing the need for clarity with the uncertainty of what you’ll come back to?"

"That’s the tricky part. I’m trying not to overthink it, but it’s hard not to wonder what will happen when I get back. I just have to trust that whatever happens, I’ll be better equipped to deal with it after some time away."

"Trusting the process can be difficult, but it sounds like you’re preparing yourself well for the unknown. Remember, this time is for you. Whatever happens afterward, you’ll have the clarity and emotional space to face it with more strength. How do you feel about that?"
"I think it’s the right move, even though it’s scary. I need this time away to figure things out for myself. I just hope when I come back, I’ll be more sure about what to do next."

"That’s a good mindset—taking the time for yourself without forcing any conclusions. It’s about giving yourself the space to process everything. How do you feel about using this time to reconnect with what makes you feel grounded?"

"That’s one of the things I’m looking forward to most. Just being out in nature, away from everything, and not having to think about the constant stress. I’m hoping it’ll help me feel like myself again."
"That sounds like a wonderful plan. Nature can offer a great way to reset emotionally. How do you feel about balancing that time for self-reflection with not overthinking things while you’re there?"
"I’ll try not to overthink. I know I tend to get stuck in my head sometimes, but I want this trip to be about letting go and just seeing what comes to me naturally."

"That’s a healthy approach. Letting things flow, rather than trying to force solutions, can often lead to more genuine clarity. How do you feel about keeping a journal while you’re away—something to capture your thoughts and emotions as they come up?"
"I hadn’t thought about that, but it sounds like a good idea. Writing things down might help me sort through what I’m feeling without getting overwhelmed."

"Exactly. Journaling can help you process your emotions in the moment without feeling the need to have immediate answers. You can look back on it later and see how your thoughts evolve. How do you feel about setting a goal for yourself during this break—something that focuses solely on your well-being?"

"I think that’s a good idea. Maybe my goal could be to just relax and let go of the pressure I’ve been feeling. I want to come back feeling more at peace with myself, regardless of what happens with my wife."

"That sounds like a meaningful and attainable goal. By focusing on your own peace of mind, you’re creating a foundation for whatever comes next. How are you feeling as you start preparing for this trip?"

"I’m still a little nervous, but I feel more ready now. I know it’s going to be tough being away from the kids and dealing with the uncertainty of what I’ll come back to, but I think it’ll be worth it."
"You’re taking a brave step, David, and that courage is important. This time away is for you, to help you grow emotionally and gain perspective. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"
"I feel more at peace with the idea of going. It’s still scary, but I think I’m ready."
"That’s a good place to be—acknowledging the fear while still moving forward. We’ll continue supporting you as you take this step. You’re doing important work."

In session 20, David discusses his mixed emotions as the trip approaches—excitement, nervousness, and fear about what he will come back to. He has explained his temporary absence to his children and plans to stay in touch with them during the trip. The therapist helps David explore his concerns about how his wife might feel during his absence, and they discuss the possibility that she might feel relief instead of missing him. David is prepared to face that reality if it comes up, but he also hopes to use the time away to figure out what he truly wants from the relationship. The therapist encourages David to reflect on his needs for emotional connection and clarity during the trip, and they discuss the importance of staying grounded while navigating these uncertainties. David feels more ready to take the trip, knowing it will help him gain perspective on both his marriage and his own well-being.
"Welcome back, David. You’ve started preparing for your time away. How are you feeling about the trip now that it's closer?"
