"I’m feeling a mix of things—excited, nervous, and still a little scared about what I’ll come back to. But I’m more ready now. I need this break."
"That’s understandable. It’s normal to feel a range of emotions when stepping into the unknown. How did the conversation with your kids go about your trip?"

"It went well. Jake understood when I explained that I needed some time to clear my head. He asked me if I was coming back, though, which hit hard. I told him, ‘Of course,’ but I can see he’s a bit anxious about it."
"It sounds like Jake is processing your absence in his own way. How did it feel to hear him ask if you were coming back?"
"It was tough. I don’t want him to think I’m leaving for good. I reassured him as much as I could, but it made me realize how much my leaving affects them, even if it's temporary."

"That’s an important realization. Your kids are sensitive to change, and your absence, even for a short period, may stir up some anxieties. How do you feel about maintaining a connection with them while you're away?"
"I thought about calling or video chatting with them every few days. I don’t want them to feel like I’ve disappeared."
"That sounds like a great idea. Staying in touch will help them feel secure, even while you're away. How do you feel about balancing that connection with your need for space and reflection?"
"I think I can handle it. I want to make sure they know I’m still here for them, but I also need this time for myself."
"That’s a healthy approach. It’s about finding that balance—being present for them without losing sight of your own needs. How are you feeling about leaving your wife behind during this time?"

[pauses] "That’s where the nervousness comes in. I keep wondering if she’ll miss me or if she’ll be relieved that I’m gone. I know I need this time, but the uncertainty about how she’ll feel while I’m away is hard to shake."

"That’s completely natural. Uncertainty can be difficult to sit with, but this time away may give both of you a clearer sense of where you stand emotionally. How are you preparing yourself for the possibility that things might feel different when you return?"

"I’m trying not to expect too much. I don’t want to come back with high hopes only to find that nothing’s changed. But at the same time, I can’t help but wonder if this break will either bring us closer or push us further apart."
"That’s an important reflection—acknowledging both possibilities without forcing an outcome. How do you think this time away will help you personally, regardless of what happens with your wife?"

"I think I’ll be able to get some clarity on what I need. I’ve been so focused on the marriage that I haven’t had time to think about my own well-being. This break is a chance for me to figure out if I still want to keep trying or if it’s time to let go."

"That’s a significant goal—to understand your own needs, separate from the pressures of the marriage. How do you feel about the possibility of coming back with a clearer sense of what you want, even if it’s different from what you expected?"

[pauses] "It’s scary, but I think it’s necessary. If I come back and realize that I don’t want to stay in the marriage, at least I’ll know. But I’m hoping the time away will help me see things more clearly."

"That’s a brave perspective, David. Allowing yourself the space to gain clarity—whether it leads to reconciliation or separation—is an important part of this process. How do you feel about handling the emotional impact if your wife feels more relieved than homesick while you’re away?"
"That’s what I’m most worried about. If she feels relieved, it might mean we’re really done. But at the same time, if that’s how she feels, I need to know. I can’t keep living in this limbo."
"Exactly. Knowing her true feelings, even if it’s difficult, can provide the clarity you need to make decisions about the future. How do you think you’ll handle that possibility if it comes up?"
"I’ll try to stay calm. I’ve been doing better at managing my emotions lately, so I think I can handle it. But it’ll still be hard to face if that’s the reality."

"It’s understandable to feel apprehensive, but you’ve shown a lot of growth in how you’re handling these challenges. No matter what you come back to, you’ll be better equipped to navigate it. How do you feel about using this time to explore what you need in a relationship, both with your wife and beyond?"

"That’s one of the things I’m hoping to figure out. I need to know if this marriage is still giving me what I need, or if I’m holding onto it out of habit. I guess I haven’t really thought about what I want in a relationship in a long time."

"That’s a powerful realization. This time away could give you the chance to reflect on your needs, independent of the relationship. What qualities or aspects of a relationship are most important to you?"

"I think I want more emotional connection. Lately, it feels like we’re just going through the motions. I miss the closeness we used to have, the feeling that we were in it together. I’m not sure if we can get that back."
"That emotional connection is a key part of any relationship. How do you feel about exploring whether that connection can be rekindled, or if it’s time to move forward in a different direction?"
"That’s what this trip is for, I guess. To figure out if it’s worth trying to rebuild that connection, or if it’s time to let go."

"It sounds like you’re approaching this with an open mind, which is important. By allowing yourself the time and space to reflect, you’re giving both yourself and your wife the opportunity to gain clarity. How do you feel about preparing emotionally for whatever comes next?"
"I think I can handle it, but it’ll be tough. I know I need to be ready for whatever happens, even if it’s not what I want. But I’m more grounded now than I was before, so I feel like I can face it."

"That’s a strong place to be, David. You’re giving yourself the space to process everything, and that emotional grounding will help you navigate whatever comes next. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"
"I feel better. Talking through this has helped me see that the vacation isn’t just about the marriage—it’s about me figuring out what I need too."
"Exactly. This time is for you, and whatever clarity it brings will help you make decisions that align with your well-being. We’ll keep supporting you through this process."

In session 21, David returns from his trip and reflects on the emotional clarity he gained while away. However, coming back to his wife was harder than expected. He hoped for a more positive reaction from her but felt she was indifferent and emotionally distant. This indifference made him realize that they are not in the same place emotionally, and David begins to question whether it’s time to let go of the marriage. The therapist supports David as he processes the painful realization that he may be the only one still fighting for the relationship. They discuss the importance of having an honest conversation with his wife about where she stands, even though David fears hearing that she’s ready to move on. The therapist helps David prepare emotionally for this conversation by encouraging him to approach it with calmness and openness, without expecting immediate answers. David leaves the session feeling more at peace with the need to face the uncertainty head-on.
"Welcome back, David. It’s been a few weeks since we last spoke. How was the trip? How are you feeling now that you’re back?"
[sighs] "It was… eye-opening. I’m not sure how to explain it. The time away gave me space to think, and it was peaceful being out in the mountains. But coming back has been harder than I expected."
"It sounds like the trip brought some clarity, but also some difficult emotions. What’s been hard about returning?"

"I thought I’d feel clearer about what to do when I got back, but instead, I feel more unsure. I had this idea that maybe things would be different—maybe she’d miss me, maybe I’d have this big realization. But it’s not that simple."
"That’s understandable. Sometimes we hope for a moment of clarity, but the reality can be more complex. How did things feel between you and your wife when you came home?"

"She was… polite. She asked me how the trip was, and we talked a little, but it didn’t feel like she was glad to have me back. It was more like she was relieved that I had my space. That hurt, to be honest."
"I can imagine that would feel painful—hoping for a sign of connection, but instead feeling more distance. How are you processing that feeling now?"

[pauses] "It made me realize that we’re not in the same place emotionally. I was hoping the time apart would help us both see things more clearly, but I think she’s just tired of the whole thing. She seems... checked out."
"It sounds like her emotional distance became more apparent after your return. Do you feel like she’s emotionally withdrawn from the relationship entirely?"
"I think so. She didn’t say it outright, but I could tell. There wasn’t any warmth. No sense of missing me or being glad I was home. It was just… indifferent."
"That indifference can be hard to face, especially when you were hoping for something more. How did you respond to her indifference emotionally?"

"I tried not to push. I didn’t want to start an argument or make things more tense, so I just kept things light. But inside, I felt pretty devastated. I had this hope that maybe things would feel different when I came back, but now it feels like nothing’s changed—if anything, it feels worse."

"That’s a difficult realization, David. It sounds like you’ve been holding onto hope for a shift in the relationship, but her response is showing you a different reality. How are you feeling about the relationship now that you’re back?"

[sighs] "I don’t know. Part of me wants to keep trying, but another part of me feels like maybe it’s time to let go. I’ve spent so much time fighting for this marriage, but it feels like I’m the only one who’s still fighting."

"That feeling of being the only one holding on must be exhausting. Do you think your wife is still emotionally invested in the marriage, or do you feel like she’s reached a point where she’s ready to move on?"

"I think she’s ready to move on, even if she hasn’t said it out loud. It’s in the way she talks—or doesn’t talk. She doesn’t engage anymore. It’s like she’s already made up her mind but is waiting for me to say it first."
"That emotional withdrawal can be painful to experience, especially when you’re still holding on. How do you feel about the idea of discussing this with her directly—asking her where she stands?"
[pauses] "I’m scared to. What if she says she’s done? I don’t know if I’m ready to hear that yet. But at the same time, I can’t keep living in this uncertainty. It’s tearing me apart."

"That’s a difficult balance—wanting clarity, but also fearing what that clarity might bring. It’s understandable to be hesitant, but having that conversation could help both of you move forward, one way or another. How do you feel about preparing for that discussion?"
"I know it has to happen. I just don’t know if I’m ready for it. I’ve been avoiding it, hoping things would somehow change on their own, but I guess that’s not going to happen."

"It sounds like you’ve been waiting for something to shift naturally, but the reality is that both of you are in a place of emotional distance. By addressing it directly, you can find out where she stands and decide how to move forward. How do you feel about preparing yourself emotionally for that conversation?"
"I think I need to. I can’t keep pretending like everything’s fine when it’s not. I just don’t know how to start the conversation without it turning into a fight or making things worse."

"That’s a valid concern. It might help to approach it with calmness and openness, rather than looking for immediate answers. Starting with a simple question—like asking her how she’s been feeling—could open the door to a deeper conversation without forcing it."
"That sounds doable. I can ask her how she feels, without pushing too hard. I just don’t know how I’ll handle it if she says she’s ready to end things."

"It’s natural to feel afraid of that outcome, but remember that having clarity—even if it’s painful—can be a way to move forward, rather than staying stuck in uncertainty. How do you feel about the idea that knowing her true feelings could help you decide what’s next for you?"

"I think it would help, even if it hurts. I’ve been living in limbo for so long that I’m not sure how to move forward anymore. Maybe hearing her say what she really feels will give me the push I need to make a decision."

"That’s an important realization. By understanding where she stands, you can make more informed decisions about your future—whether that means trying to rebuild or letting go. How do you feel about balancing the emotional toll of this conversation with your need for clarity?"

"I think I’ll need to stay calm and not react emotionally. It’s going to be hard, but I know I can’t let my emotions take over. I’ve been doing better at managing them, but this conversation is going to be tough."

"You’ve made great progress in managing your emotions, and that emotional grounding will be important in this conversation. Staying calm and open, without expecting a specific outcome, can help keep the discussion from escalating. How do you feel about focusing on staying present during the conversation, rather than trying to control the outcome?"
"I think that’s the best way to approach it. I can’t control what she’s going to say or how she feels, but I can control how I respond. I need to stay present and not let my fears take over."

"That’s a strong approach, David. By staying present and focusing on your own emotional well-being, you’ll be better prepared to handle whatever comes up. How do you feel about setting a time to have this conversation with her?"
"I think I’ll do it this weekend. We need to talk, and I can’t keep putting it off. It’s scary, but I know it has to happen."

"That’s a brave decision. Taking the step to have this conversation shows a lot of courage and self-awareness. We’ll continue to support you through this process, and you’re not alone in facing this."
"Thanks. I appreciate that. It’s going to be tough, but I feel more ready now."
"You’ve come a long way, David, and you’re showing a lot of emotional strength. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"
"I feel more at peace. It’s still scary, but I know I need to face this and get some clarity. I just hope we can talk without it turning into a fight."
"That’s a good place to be—acknowledging the fear but still moving forward with intention. We’ll keep working on this together, and no matter what happens, you’re doing important emotional work."

In session 22, David shares that he had the conversation with his wife about her emotional distance, and she admitted that she’s unsure if she wants to keep trying in the marriage. David stayed calm during the conversation, but he was devastated by the reality of her feelings. The therapist helps David process the possibility of letting go of the marriage, as he begins to accept that they may not be on the same page anymore. They explore the next steps, including the potential for separation and how to handle the practical aspects, such as custody of the kids and financial considerations. David expresses fear about the future, but also a sense of relief at the idea of no longer living in uncertainty. The therapist supports David in navigating the emotional toll of separation and encourages him to stay grounded for the sake of his children. David leaves the session feeling more at peace, even though the road ahead is still uncertain.
"Welcome back, David. Last time, you were preparing to have an important conversation with your wife about where she stands emotionally. How did it go?"

[sighs] "It was rough. We talked, and she was pretty honest. She said she’s been feeling disconnected for a long time, and she’s not sure if she wants to keep trying. It hurt to hear, but at least now I know where she stands."
"That must have been difficult to hear. How did you handle the conversation emotionally, knowing that she was feeling so uncertain?"
"I stayed calm. I didn’t want to argue or make things worse. I just listened to her, and I tried to stay as present as I could. But inside, I was pretty devastated."
"It’s a big emotional weight to carry, especially when you’ve been holding onto hope. How are you processing the reality of her emotional distance now that you’ve had time to reflect?"

"I think I’m starting to accept it. As much as I don’t want to let go, I can’t ignore how she feels. It’s clear that we’re not on the same page anymore, and I can’t keep trying to fix something if she’s not invested."

"That acceptance is an important step, even though it’s painful. It’s hard to come to terms with the fact that the relationship may not be what it once was. How are you feeling about the possibility of letting go?"
[pauses] "I’m scared, to be honest. I’ve spent so much of my life focused on this marriage, and the idea of it ending feels overwhelming. But at the same time, I know I can’t keep living like this."

"That fear is completely understandable. You’ve invested so much emotionally, and the uncertainty of what comes next can feel daunting. How do you feel about the idea of moving forward on your own if that’s where things lead?"

"I think I’ll be okay eventually. It’s just hard to picture what my life will look like without her in it. But I’ve been doing better with the kids, and that’s been keeping me grounded. I think if I focus on them and on myself, I’ll get through it."

"That’s a healthy mindset, David. Focusing on your relationship with your kids and your own emotional well-being will give you the stability you need, regardless of what happens in your marriage. How did the conversation with your wife end? Did you reach any decisions?"
"We didn’t make any final decisions, but it felt like we were both leaning toward separation. She didn’t say she wanted a divorce outright, but she said she doesn’t know if she can keep doing this."
"It sounds like you’re both feeling the weight of the uncertainty. How do you feel about the idea of separation becoming more of a reality?"
[pauses] "I think it might be time. We’ve been in this holding pattern for so long, and neither of us is happy. As much as I hate to admit it, maybe we’re better off apart."

"That’s a big realization, David. Acknowledging that separation might be the best option is an important step. How do you feel about discussing this further with her, and possibly taking the next steps toward separation?"

"I’m scared, but I think we need to have that conversation. We can’t keep avoiding it. If we’re going to separate, we need to figure out how to do it in a way that’s best for the kids and for ourselves."

"It’s a brave decision to face that possibility head-on. By discussing it openly and calmly, you and your wife can find a way to navigate this with as little conflict as possible. How do you feel about preparing for that conversation emotionally?"
"I’m trying to stay grounded, but it’s hard. The thought of splitting up is terrifying, but I know we can’t keep living in this limbo. I think I’m ready to talk about it, even if it’s going to hurt."

"That’s a big step forward, David. Having that conversation, even though it’s difficult, can help both of you move toward more clarity. How are you feeling about the practical aspects of separation—like custody of the kids and living arrangements?"

"That’s the part that stresses me out the most. I don’t want to fight over the kids, and I don’t want to put them through any more tension. I want to make sure they’re okay, no matter what happens between me and my wife."

"That’s an important priority. By focusing on what’s best for the kids, you and your wife can approach the separation with their well-being at the forefront. How do you feel about discussing custody and living arrangements with her?"
"I think we can talk about it calmly. We both love the kids, and I don’t think either of us wants to make this harder on them than it has to be. I just hope we can keep things civil."

"It sounds like you’re both committed to making this as smooth as possible for the kids, which is crucial. How do you feel about the financial aspects of separation—things like alimony and dividing assets?"

[pauses] "That’s where it gets tricky. We haven’t talked about it yet, but I know it’s going to be a big part of the discussion. I just want to be fair, but I’m worried about how we’re going to manage everything."

"It’s understandable to feel anxious about that. Financial discussions can be challenging, but approaching them with transparency and fairness will help keep things on track. How do you feel about preparing for those conversations as part of this process?"
"I think I’ll need some help with that. I don’t want things to get messy, but I know we have to talk about it sooner or later. I’m just hoping we can handle it without turning it into a fight."

"That’s a good approach—keeping things calm and focused on fairness. We can continue to support you as you prepare for those conversations. How are you feeling overall, now that you’ve started to accept the possibility of separation?"
"It’s a mix of emotions. Part of me feels sad and scared, but another part of me feels relieved. I’ve been holding onto this marriage for so long, and maybe letting go is the right thing to do."

"That relief is a sign that you’re beginning to find some emotional clarity. It’s okay to feel a mix of emotions—sadness, fear, and even relief. How do you feel about continuing to process those emotions as you move forward?"

"I think it’s going to take time. I’m not expecting to feel better overnight, but I’m starting to see that this might be what we need. I just want to make sure I’m doing the right thing for myself and the kids."

"That’s a healthy perspective, David. Giving yourself time to process these emotions is important, and focusing on what’s best for you and the kids will help guide your decisions. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"
"I feel more at peace. It’s still scary, but I think I’m ready to take the next steps. We need to talk about it, and I think I can handle it now."
"You’re showing a lot of emotional strength, David. We’ll continue supporting you through this process, and you’re taking important steps toward clarity and healing."

In session 23, David discusses the conversation with his wife about separation, where they agreed to prioritize their children's well-being. David reflects on the emotional toll of co-parenting, his fear of letting go, and the need to grieve and rediscover his own needs.
"Welcome back, David. Last time we spoke, you were preparing for the difficult conversation with your wife about the possibility of separation. How did it go?"

[sighs deeply] "It was rough, but we had the conversation. She admitted that she doesn’t feel like we can keep going like this. She said she’s tired of pretending, and honestly, I don’t blame her. It hurt to hear, but part of me knew it was coming."
"That must have been incredibly painful to hear, even if you were anticipating it. How did you respond in the moment?"

"I stayed calm, mostly. I told her I understood how she felt, and that I’ve been feeling the same way. We both agreed that we can’t keep living in this constant state of tension. It was hard to say, but I think it was a relief for both of us to finally admit it."
"It sounds like there was a sense of mutual understanding, even in the midst of the pain. How did it feel to finally speak openly about the possibility of separating?"

"It was a relief, honestly. I’ve been holding onto this fear for so long, but when we finally talked about it, I felt like a weight had been lifted. I didn’t realize how much the uncertainty was eating away at me until we started talking."
"That’s a significant step forward, David. It seems like confronting the possibility of separation has given you both some clarity. What were the main points that came up in the conversation?"

"We talked about the kids, mostly. We both agreed that we need to make this as easy as possible on them, if we do separate. Neither of us wants to put them through a messy divorce. We also talked about practical things—like living arrangements, finances, and how we’ll handle custody."

"It sounds like you’re both approaching this with a focus on the well-being of the kids, which is important. How did you feel discussing those practical aspects, especially when it comes to custody and finances?"

"It was tough, but we managed to keep it civil. We agreed that the kids should stay in the house with her, at least for now, since they’re used to it. I’ll take them on weekends and maybe a night or two during the week. Financially, we haven’t worked out all the details, but I told her I want to be fair and support her and the kids."

"That’s a thoughtful and responsible approach, David. Keeping the children’s stability in mind while you navigate these changes is crucial. How are you feeling about the idea of not being in the house with them full-time?"

[pauses] "That’s the hardest part. I love my kids, and the thought of not seeing them every day is gut-wrenching. But I know this is what’s best for them. I don’t want them to grow up in a house where their parents are always fighting."
"That’s a difficult reality to face, but it sounds like you’re prioritizing their emotional well-being. How do you feel about the idea of co-parenting and building a new routine with them?"
"I think we can make it work. My wife and I aren’t on bad terms, so I think we can figure out a way to co-parent without too much conflict. I’m just worried about how the kids will handle it."
"That’s a valid concern. How do you plan to explain the situation to them when the time comes?"

"We haven’t talked to them yet. I think we’re both dreading that conversation. Jake’s old enough to understand what’s happening, but Lily and Emily… I’m not sure how they’ll react. We want to be honest with them, but we also don’t want to overwhelm them."
"That’s a delicate balance to strike—being honest without overwhelming them. How do you feel about approaching that conversation together with your wife, to show a united front for the kids?"
"I think that’s the best way to do it. We need to let them know that even though we won’t be living together, we’re still both their parents, and we both love them. I just hope they’ll be okay."
"It’s natural to worry about how they’ll react, but approaching it with honesty and reassurance can help them feel more secure. Have you thought about when you’ll have that conversation?"
"We were thinking about doing it this weekend. It’s going to be hard, but we can’t keep putting it off. They need to know what’s going on."
"That’s a brave decision, David. The sooner they know, the sooner they can begin to adjust. How are you preparing yourself emotionally for that conversation?"

[pauses] "I’m trying to stay strong for them. I don’t want to break down in front of the kids, but it’s going to be tough. I’m afraid of how they’ll take it, especially Jake. He’s been asking questions lately, and I think he knows something’s up."
"It’s understandable that Jake might be sensing the tension. Kids are often more aware than we realize. How do you plan to handle his questions and concerns during the conversation?"

"I think I’ll just be honest with him. I don’t want to sugarcoat things, but I also don’t want to scare him. I’ll tell him that Mommy and Daddy love him, and that we’re both going to be there for him, even if we’re not living together."

"That sounds like a thoughtful and reassuring approach. By being honest and supportive, you’re giving Jake the security he needs during this transition. How are you feeling about navigating this new phase of co-parenting with your wife?"
"It’s going to be an adjustment, but I think we can handle it. We both love the kids, and we want what’s best for them. As long as we keep that in mind, I think we can make it work."

"It sounds like you and your wife are committed to putting the kids first, which is important. How do you feel about finding a new routine for yourself now that separation is becoming more of a reality?"

[sighs] "It’s strange. I’ve been so focused on the marriage for so long that I haven’t really thought about what my life will look like without it. I guess I’ll need to figure out a new routine—something that works for me and the kids."

"That’s an important step, David—finding a routine that supports both you and your relationship with your kids. How do you feel about taking some time to focus on your own emotional needs during this transition?"
"I think I need to. I’ve been putting myself on the back burner for so long that I’m not even sure what I need anymore. Maybe now’s the time to figure that out."

"That’s a crucial realization—taking time to focus on your own needs will help you stay grounded as you navigate this transition. What are some things you think you might want to explore for yourself moving forward?"

"I don’t know yet, honestly. I’ve always been so wrapped up in being a husband and a father that I haven’t really thought about what I want. Maybe I’ll start with small things—hobbies, spending time with friends. I don’t know."

"That’s a good place to start—small steps toward rediscovering what brings you fulfillment outside of the marriage. How do you feel about giving yourself the space to explore new interests and reconnect with yourself?"
"I think it’ll be good for me. I’ve been so focused on keeping everything together that I’ve lost sight of myself. It’s going to be weird, though, being on my own again."
"It’s a big adjustment, but it sounds like you’re ready to start focusing on yourself and what you need. How do you feel about balancing that with your responsibilities as a father?"
"I think I can manage it. The kids will always come first, but I know I need to take care of myself too. I’m starting to see that if I’m not okay, I can’t be the best father for them."
"That’s an important realization. Taking care of yourself allows you to be more present and emotionally available for your kids. How are you feeling as you move forward with these changes?"
"I feel more at peace. It’s still hard, but I know this is the right thing to do—for me, for my wife, and for the kids. We can’t keep pretending everything’s okay when it’s not."
"That’s a powerful insight, David. Acknowledging that this change is what’s best for everyone shows a lot of emotional growth. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"
"I feel better. Talking through it has helped me see that we can make this work, even if it’s not how I pictured things turning out."
"You’ve come a long way, David. We’ll keep supporting you through this process, and you’re showing incredible emotional strength. You’re doing important work for yourself and your family."

In session 24, David discusses telling his children about the separation, with Jake taking it the hardest. David struggles with guilt but reassures Jake it’s not his fault. The therapist helps David process his emotions, emphasizing the importance of vulnerability to help his children feel safe. They discuss the need for David to grieve the end of the marriage while balancing his role as a father. The session concludes with David reflecting on rediscovering himself and feeling more grounded as he prepares for the next phase of his life.
"Welcome back, David. Last session, you and your wife were preparing to tell the kids about your decision to separate. How did that conversation go?"

[sighs] "It was harder than I thought it would be. We sat them down, and we explained that we weren’t going to be living together anymore. Jake took it the hardest. He asked a lot of questions—why we couldn’t work it out, if it was his fault. That really hit me."
"That must have been incredibly difficult. How did you respond to Jake’s questions, especially when he asked if it was his fault?"

"I told him over and over that it wasn’t his fault—that this was something between me and his mom. But he’s smart. He kept asking why we couldn’t fix things, and I didn’t really know what to say. It broke my heart."
"It sounds like Jake is struggling to understand why his family is changing, and that’s a normal reaction for a child in this situation. How are you processing his reaction emotionally?"
"I felt like I failed him. I tried to hold it together for him and Lily, but hearing him ask those questions—there’s no easy way to explain to a kid why his parents are breaking up. I felt helpless."
"That feeling of helplessness is understandable, David. You’re trying to protect your kids while also dealing with your own emotions. How did Lily and Emily react during the conversation?"

"Lily was quieter. She’s younger, so I think she doesn’t fully understand yet. She asked if we were still going to read stories together, and that hit me hard too. Emily’s too young to really grasp it, but she was clingier than usual."

"It sounds like each of them is processing the separation in their own way, and they’re looking for reassurance. How are you balancing being there for them while also managing your own emotional response?"

"I’m trying to be strong for them, but it’s hard. I feel like I’m falling apart on the inside, but I don’t want them to see that. I want to make sure they know that I’m still here for them, even if things are changing."

"That’s a lot of emotional weight to carry. You’re doing your best to stay strong for them, but it’s important to also give yourself space to process what you’re going through. How do you feel about giving yourself permission to feel those emotions, even in front of your kids?"
[pauses] "I guess I’ve been afraid to show them how much this is affecting me. I don’t want them to feel like they have to take care of me, but I also know I can’t keep pretending everything’s fine."

"That’s an important realization. Allowing yourself to be vulnerable in front of your kids—showing them that it’s okay to have difficult emotions—can actually help them process their own feelings. How do you feel about sharing some of your own emotions with them in a way that feels appropriate?"

"I hadn’t thought about it like that. Maybe I do need to be more open with them. I want them to know that it’s okay to feel sad or confused, but I’ve been so focused on holding it together that I’ve been hiding how I feel."

"It’s a natural instinct to want to protect them, but sharing your emotions can help create an environment where they feel safe to express theirs. How do you think Jake, especially, would respond if he saw that you’re also struggling with this change?"
"I think it might help him. He’s been bottling up a lot lately, and maybe if he sees that I’m feeling the same way, he won’t feel so alone. I just don’t want to burden him."

"It’s about finding that balance—showing him that it’s okay to feel sad without making him feel responsible for your emotions. How do you feel about starting that conversation with him, letting him know that it’s okay to talk about how he’s feeling?"

"I think it’s the right thing to do. He’s been holding back, and I don’t want him to feel like he has to be strong all the time. I’ll talk to him this week, try to create a space where he feels safe to open up."

"That’s a compassionate approach, David. Giving Jake that emotional space will be important for both of you. How are you feeling about your own emotions now that the separation is becoming more real?"

[sighs] "I feel… strange. Part of me is relieved, like we’re finally moving forward. But another part of me feels like I’m losing everything I’ve built. It’s this constant push and pull between wanting to move on and feeling like I’m letting go of a huge part of my life."

"That push and pull is a natural part of the grieving process. You’re navigating the loss of a relationship, even if it’s one that needed to end. How do you feel about allowing yourself to grieve that loss, while also looking ahead to what comes next?"

"I guess I haven’t really let myself grieve. I’ve been so focused on the logistics and the kids that I haven’t had time to just sit with what’s happening. Maybe that’s what I need to do—let myself feel the loss before I can move on."

"That’s a crucial step, David—acknowledging the grief and giving yourself permission to feel it. Grieving doesn’t mean you’re not moving forward; it’s part of the process of healing. How do you feel about creating space for that grief in the coming weeks?"
"I think I need to. I’ve been trying to push it aside, but I know it’s there. If I don’t face it, it’s just going to keep building up. I don’t want to carry this with me forever."

"That’s an important realization. Facing the grief head-on will help you release it in a healthy way, rather than letting it fester. How do you feel about finding some quiet time for yourself to reflect and process these emotions?"
"I think that’s what I need. Maybe I’ll take a day or two to just be alone and let myself feel everything. It’s been a whirlwind, and I haven’t really had time to just sit with it all."

"That sounds like a healthy way to process everything. Giving yourself that time will help you gain clarity and emotional release. How do you feel about balancing that time for yourself with staying present for your kids during this transition?"
"It’s going to be hard, but I know I need to do both. I can’t be there for them if I’m not okay myself. I need to take care of my own emotions so I can be the father they need me to be."
"Exactly. Taking care of yourself will allow you to show up more fully for your kids. How are you feeling about what comes next—both in terms of co-parenting and your own personal life?"

"I’m still figuring that out. The co-parenting part, I think we can handle. But when it comes to my personal life, I’m not really sure what I want yet. I’ve been so wrapped up in the marriage that I don’t even know who I am outside of it."

"That’s a big realization, David. Rediscovering who you are outside of the marriage will be a significant part of this next chapter. How do you feel about exploring that—finding out what brings you joy, fulfillment, and peace?"
"It’s a little scary, but also kind of exciting. I haven’t had time to think about myself in a long time. I guess this is a chance to start over, even if it’s not how I pictured things."
"That’s a powerful way to look at it—an opportunity to reconnect with yourself and create a life that aligns with who you are now. How do you feel about starting that journey, step by step?"
"I think I’m ready. It’s going to be hard, but I can’t keep living in the past. I need to figure out what comes next for me, and I think this is the time to do it."
"You’ve shown incredible strength, David, and this next phase will be about honoring that strength while also allowing yourself to grow and heal. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"
"I feel better. It’s still hard, but I know I’m moving in the right direction. I just need to keep taking it one step at a time."
"That’s exactly right—one step at a time. You’re doing important emotional work, and we’ll keep supporting you through this process."

In session 25, David reflects on the challenges of adjusting to his new family routine after the separation. He notices Jake’s emotional withdrawal and his wife’s continued distance. The therapist helps David explore the tension in his marriage and how avoidance of deeper conversations has contributed to emotional distance. They also discuss David’s role as a peacemaker in his family, drawing connections to his childhood. David begins to realize the need to let go of the idea of 'fixing' everything and starts to reflect on his own needs outside of that role.
"Welcome back, David. Last time, we spoke about the conversation with your kids and the emotional weight you've been carrying. How has this past week been for you and your family?"

[sighs] "It’s been tough. We’ve tried to settle into this new routine, but it feels like everything’s changed. The kids are adjusting, but I can tell Jake is still struggling. He’s been quieter, and sometimes, he just looks at me like he’s trying to figure out what’s going on."
"It sounds like Jake is processing a lot internally. Have you had any more conversations with him about how he’s feeling?"
"We talked a little. I tried to get him to open up, but he just said, ‘I’m fine.’ It’s like he doesn’t want to worry me. I can tell he’s upset, but he’s holding back."
"That’s difficult, especially when you can sense that he’s struggling but he’s not expressing it. How did that make you feel when he said he was fine?"

"I felt frustrated. I know he’s not fine, but I didn’t want to push him too hard. I don’t want him to feel like he has to take care of me emotionally, but I also don’t want him to keep everything bottled up."
"That’s a delicate balance to navigate. You’re right in wanting to protect him, but there’s also value in creating space where he feels safe to share. How have Lily and Emily been adjusting?"

"Lily’s been more clingy, especially with her mom. She asks a lot of questions, like if I’m coming home every day, and it breaks my heart. Emily’s too young to really understand, but she’s definitely been more sensitive to the changes. I think the tension is affecting her too, even if she can’t verbalize it."
"It sounds like each of your kids is reacting in their own way, trying to make sense of the changes. How has your wife been during all of this? Have you had any more discussions about the future?"

"We’ve been civil, but distant. We’re doing our best to keep things normal for the kids, but it’s hard. There’s this underlying tension between us. We’re coexisting, but it feels like we’re living separate lives now."

"That emotional distance is understandable given everything that’s happened, but it can also create more stress in the home. How are you feeling about the possibility of talking more openly with her about where things stand between you?"

"I think I need to, but I’m not sure how to start that conversation. Every time we talk about something deeper, it ends up feeling tense. We’re both trying to avoid conflict, but that’s making it harder to be real with each other."

"That avoidance of conflict might be keeping things calm on the surface, but it’s also preventing deeper emotional clarity. How do you feel about finding a way to talk with her about your relationship in a more open and non-confrontational way?"
"I think it would help, but I’m not sure how to approach it. I don’t want to push her away even more, but I also don’t want to keep pretending like everything’s fine when it’s not."

"It’s a tough balance. Maybe framing the conversation as a way to understand how both of you are feeling, without necessarily looking for solutions right away, could help ease some of the tension. How do you feel about that approach?"

"I think that could work. We’ve both been tiptoeing around our feelings, and maybe it’s time we just talked openly, even if it’s hard. I want to know where she stands emotionally, and I think I need to share where I’m at too."

"That’s a positive step, David. Creating that space for honest communication will help both of you understand where you are, even if it doesn’t lead to immediate answers. How do you feel about focusing on the emotional side of the conversation rather than the practical aspects for now?"

"I think that’s a good idea. We’ve been so focused on the logistics—who’s staying where, when I’ll see the kids—that we haven’t really talked about how we’re both feeling. Maybe that’s what’s been missing."

"Now that we’ve discussed your family and the immediate emotional dynamics, I’d like to shift our focus to something deeper—your personal experiences and associations. When you think about your current situation, are there any memories from your past that come to mind? Any connections to your childhood?"

[pauses] "It’s funny you mention that. I’ve been thinking about my parents a lot lately. When I was a kid, they fought constantly, but they never got divorced. I always wondered why they stayed together, even when they clearly weren’t happy."
"That’s an interesting connection. How do you think witnessing your parents’ dynamic shaped your view of marriage and conflict?"

"I think it made me believe that staying together, no matter what, was the right thing to do. I remember feeling like it was my job to keep the peace between them. I’d try to distract them when they argued or make them laugh. I guess I learned to avoid conflict by trying to fix everything."

"It sounds like you took on the role of the peacemaker at a young age, feeling responsible for maintaining harmony in the family. Do you see any parallels between that role and the way you’ve approached your own marriage?"
"Yeah, definitely. I’ve been doing the same thing with my wife—trying to avoid arguments, stepping in to fix things before they get worse. But now I’m realizing that maybe I can’t fix this."

"That’s an important realization, David. It’s possible that the pressure you put on yourself to keep the peace in your parents’ marriage carried over into your own. How do you feel about letting go of that need to fix everything?"

[pauses] "It’s scary. I’ve always felt like it was my job to hold things together. But maybe I’ve been holding onto something that’s already broken. Letting go feels like giving up, but maybe it’s not."

"Letting go doesn’t have to mean giving up. It can mean accepting that you’ve done all you can and that it’s okay to step back. How do you feel about the idea of releasing that responsibility, especially when it’s something you’ve carried for so long?"
"I think it would be freeing, but also terrifying. It’s been my identity for so long—being the one who fixes things, keeps everything together. I’m not sure who I am without that role."

"That’s a profound insight. If you’ve spent much of your life defining yourself through that role of fixing and holding things together, it makes sense that stepping away from it would feel disorienting. But it also opens up the possibility of exploring who you are outside of that role. What comes to mind when you think about who you are, beyond being the peacemaker?"

[pauses, thinking deeply] "Honestly, I’m not sure. I’ve spent so long making sure everything is okay for everyone else that I haven’t really thought about what I need. Even as a kid, I didn’t focus on myself much—I was always worried about my parents, trying to make things better for them."

"That’s a significant part of your emotional history—prioritizing others’ needs over your own, starting from childhood. It sounds like that pattern of focusing outward rather than inward has continued into your adult life. How do you feel about the idea of shifting that focus back to yourself?"

"It feels strange. I don’t really know what that would look like. I’ve always been the one who’s there for other people—whether it’s my parents, my wife, or my kids. I guess I don’t even know what I want or need anymore."

"That’s a powerful acknowledgment. You’ve been carrying the weight of others’ emotions for so long that your own needs might feel unfamiliar. Let’s take a moment to explore this. When you think about your childhood, were there any moments when you felt like your own needs were being met? Any times when you were able to focus on yourself?"
[sighs] "Not really. I can’t think of any specific moments. It was always about keeping the peace, trying to make sure everyone else was okay. I guess I just assumed that was my role."
"It sounds like that assumption was ingrained early on. Do you think there were any moments when you wanted to express your own needs, but felt like you couldn’t?"

"Yeah, there were times when I wanted to say something, but I didn’t. I remember one time when my parents were arguing—really loudly—and I wanted to ask them to stop, to tell them how it was making me feel. But I didn’t. I just went to my room and put my headphones on, like I always did."

"That’s a significant memory. You learned to retreat inward rather than express your needs, and that pattern seems to have continued into adulthood. How do you feel about exploring that memory further—about what it meant for you emotionally at the time?"

[pauses] "It felt like I didn’t matter. Like what I wanted didn’t matter as long as they were fighting. I guess I told myself that if I could just keep them calm, then everything would be okay. But deep down, I was angry. Angry that they didn’t see how it was affecting me."

"That’s a lot to carry, especially as a child. You were dealing with complex emotions—anger, helplessness, and perhaps a sense of invisibility. How do you feel about connecting that anger and invisibility to how you’ve handled conflict in your adult life, particularly with your wife?"

"I think I’ve been doing the same thing. I’ve been avoiding conflict with her because it feels safer. But inside, I’ve been angry. Angry that she doesn’t see how much I’ve been sacrificing, how hard I’ve been trying. But I’ve never said it out loud. I’ve just pushed it down, like I always did with my parents."

"That’s a profound connection, David. It sounds like the anger and frustration you felt as a child have been resurfacing in your marriage, but instead of expressing it, you’ve continued the pattern of pushing it down. How do you feel about the idea of giving that anger a voice, of allowing yourself to express it in a healthy way?"
[pauses] "It’s scary. I don’t want to explode or say something I’ll regret, but I also know I can’t keep holding it in. It’s been eating at me for a long time."

"That fear is understandable, especially since you’ve spent so much time avoiding conflict. But giving your emotions a voice doesn’t have to mean exploding. It can be about finding a space where you can express what you’re feeling without needing to ‘fix’ anything in that moment. How do you feel about creating that space for yourself?"

"I think I need that. I’ve been carrying all of this for so long, and I’m starting to realize that it’s okay to let it out. Maybe it’s time I stop trying to hold everything together and just be honest about how I feel."

"That’s a significant breakthrough, David. Allowing yourself to be honest about your feelings—without trying to fix or avoid conflict—can open up a new way of relating to others and yourself. How do you feel about starting this process of giving your emotions space to exist, even if it feels unfamiliar?"
"It feels like a relief, but also like stepping into something I don’t fully understand yet. I’m not used to putting myself first or even acknowledging what I need. But I think I’m ready to start."

"That’s a powerful step forward. This process of rediscovering your needs and giving yourself the space to express them will take time, but it’s an essential part of your emotional growth. How do you feel about reflecting more on your childhood as a way to better understand how these patterns developed?"
"I think it’ll help. The more we talk about it, the more I’m seeing how much my childhood shaped who I am and how I handle things. Maybe if I can understand that better, I can start changing it."

"That’s exactly the goal—by exploring your childhood experiences and the roles you took on, we can begin to unravel the patterns that have influenced your life. This awareness will help you create new ways of being that align more with who you are now. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"

"I feel lighter. It’s like I’m finally starting to understand where all of this comes from, and that’s helping me figure out what I need to change. I know it’s going to take time, but I feel more hopeful now."

"You’ve made incredible progress, David. The work we’re doing here is laying the foundation for your emotional healing and growth. We’ll keep exploring these connections in future sessions, and you’re taking important steps toward discovering a deeper sense of self."

In session 26, David discusses his growing awareness of how much energy he’s spent trying to fix everyone’s problems. The therapist helps him explore the anxiety and relief he feels as he steps back from this role. David acknowledges that he’s unsure of who he is without being the fixer and is beginning to explore his own needs. They also revisit David’s childhood experiences and how his role in his parents’ conflicts has shaped his approach to his marriage. David is starting to give himself permission to feel and express his emotions, especially his suppressed anger.

"Welcome back, David. Last time, we delved deeply into the role you’ve taken on as the peacemaker in your family and how that pattern has influenced your marriage. How have things been this past week, both at home and in terms of your own reflections?"

[sighs] "It’s been a mixed week. I’ve been thinking a lot about what we talked about, about how I’ve always tried to fix everything. But at home, things are still… tense. My wife and I haven’t really had that conversation yet. I think we’re both avoiding it."

"That tension can be hard to sit with, especially when you’re trying to process your own emotions. How does it feel to recognize that you and your wife are avoiding deeper conversations, even though you’re more aware of your own patterns now?"
"It’s frustrating. I know we need to talk, but every time I think about bringing it up, I get this knot in my stomach. I don’t want to make things worse. But I also can’t keep living in this limbo."

"That frustration makes sense. You’re at a point where you’re more conscious of your emotional needs, but the avoidance creates a barrier to addressing them. How do you feel about pushing past that discomfort and initiating the conversation?"

[pauses] "I know I need to do it. I just… don’t know how to start. I’m afraid that if I say the wrong thing, it’ll turn into an argument. And I really don’t want to fight, especially in front of the kids."

"That’s understandable. Avoiding conflict has been a long-standing pattern for you, and it’s difficult to shift that, especially when the stakes feel high. How do you feel about approaching the conversation with a focus on understanding each other’s feelings, rather than trying to solve everything in one go?"

"I think that could work. If I frame it as just wanting to know how she’s feeling, maybe it’ll feel less like a confrontation. But part of me is still scared that it’ll bring up things neither of us wants to face."

"That fear is natural, especially when the conversation could lead to difficult truths. But by opening up that space for honesty, you may find more clarity—both for yourself and for her. How do you feel about the possibility that facing those truths might actually help both of you, even if it’s painful?"

[sighs deeply] "I think it’s what we need. We’ve been avoiding this for too long, and I can’t keep pretending like everything’s okay when it’s not. I need to know where we stand, even if it’s hard to hear."

"That’s a courageous step, David. Acknowledging that the truth, no matter how difficult, is better than staying in this unresolved space is a significant shift. How are you feeling about taking that step in the next few days?"
"I’m still nervous, but I think I’m ready. I can’t keep holding this in. It’s time we talk, even if it’s uncomfortable."

"That readiness is important. It’s a sign that you’re prepared to move toward emotional clarity, even if it means facing some discomfort. How do you think this conversation will impact your relationship with your kids?"

"That’s one of my biggest worries. I don’t want them to feel like they’re caught in the middle. Jake’s been more withdrawn lately, and I think he knows something’s up. Lily’s still asking if I’m coming home every day, and it kills me that I can’t give her a clear answer."

"It sounds like your kids are picking up on the emotional undercurrents, even if they can’t fully understand what’s happening. How do you feel about being more open with them in a way that’s age-appropriate, letting them know that both you and their mom are figuring things out?"

"I think I need to. They’re smarter than I give them credit for. I’ve been trying to shield them from everything, but maybe it’s better to let them know that it’s okay to feel confused or worried, that we’re working through it."

"Exactly. Letting them know that it’s okay to have questions, even if you don’t have all the answers yet, can help them feel more secure. How do you feel about balancing that openness with maintaining their sense of stability?"
"I want to protect them, but I also don’t want to lie. I think if we’re honest with them—at least as much as we can be—it might help ease some of their anxiety."

"That’s a thoughtful approach, David. You’re focusing on giving them a sense of emotional safety, even in the midst of uncertainty. Now, I’d like to shift to something deeper—your emotional journey in all of this. When you think about the way you’ve approached conflict and emotions throughout your life, does anything from your childhood stand out?"

[pauses] "Yeah, I keep coming back to those fights my parents had. It’s weird how much that still affects me. I remember trying so hard to get them to stop fighting, but I never succeeded. I guess part of me feels like I’ve been failing at the same thing with my wife."

"That’s a powerful realization. It sounds like there’s a part of you that still carries the emotional weight of not being able to ‘fix’ things in your parents’ relationship, and that’s carried over into your own marriage. How do you feel about that connection?"

"It makes sense. I’ve been trying to do the same thing—keep the peace, avoid the fights, and fix things before they break. But now I’m realizing that I can’t control everything, and that’s a hard pill to swallow."

"That’s a difficult truth to come to terms with—the idea that you can’t always prevent conflict or fix things, no matter how hard you try. How do you feel about letting go of that need for control, particularly in your marriage?"

[pauses] "It’s terrifying. But at the same time, it feels like a relief. I’ve been holding on so tightly for so long, and I’m starting to see that maybe it’s okay to let go. Maybe it’s not my job to fix everything."

"That’s a significant breakthrough, David. Letting go of that responsibility can open up space for you to focus on your own needs and emotional health. How do you feel about giving yourself permission to step back from being the fixer and allowing yourself to just be?"

"It’s a strange feeling. I’ve spent so long trying to hold everything together that I don’t really know what it’s like to just be. But I think I need to try. I can’t keep carrying all this weight alone."

"That’s an important step—allowing yourself to release that weight and focus on your own emotional well-being. When you think about your childhood, do you remember any moments where you felt like your own needs were finally recognized?"

[sighs] "Not really. It was always about them. I don’t think I ever really had a chance to focus on myself. Even when I wanted to, there was always something going on that pulled me back into the role of the fixer."

"That’s a significant insight. It sounds like you’ve been in that role for so long that it’s become part of your identity, even when it wasn’t what you wanted. How do you feel about the idea of exploring who you are without that role?"
"It’s scary. I don’t know who I am without it. But I think it’s time I find out. I can’t keep living like this—trying to fix everything and never focusing on myself. It’s exhausting."

"That’s a powerful realization, David. This process of discovering who you are outside of the fixer role will take time, but it’s an important journey. How do you feel about taking some time to reflect on what you truly want and need for yourself?"
"I think it’s time. I’ve spent so long focusing on everyone else that I don’t even know what I need anymore. But I want to find out. I think that’s the only way I can move forward."

"That’s a significant step forward, David. Giving yourself permission to explore your own needs, separate from the role you’ve taken on, is an important part of your emotional healing. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"
"I feel more at peace. It’s like I’m finally starting to let go of some of that weight I’ve been carrying. I know it’s going to take time, but I’m ready to start focusing on myself."
"You’ve made incredible progress, David. This journey of self-discovery and emotional healing is a vital part of your growth, and we’ll continue supporting you through it."

In session 27, David reflects on his growing awareness of stepping away from his fixer role, noticing both relief and anxiety as he lets go of control. He shares how this shift has impacted his relationship with his wife and children, allowing him to be more present rather than reactive. The therapist helps David explore the deeper emotions, including anger, that he’s suppressed since childhood. David begins to realize that embracing the messiness of life, including conflict, is key to his emotional growth and healing.
"Welcome back, David. Last time, we talked about letting go of the role of the fixer, and how that’s shaped your life. How have you been processing that over the past week?"

[sighs deeply] "It’s been on my mind a lot. I’ve started to notice just how much of my energy goes into making sure everyone else is okay. Even little things—like when the kids are fighting or when my wife is in a bad mood—I feel this instinct to jump in and fix it."
"It sounds like you’re becoming more aware of how automatic that instinct is. How has it felt to notice that pattern in your day-to-day life?"

"It’s strange. On one hand, it’s exhausting because I’m realizing how often I do it. But on the other hand, it’s kind of freeing to just notice it without always acting on it. I’ve caught myself a few times wanting to step in, but I’ve stopped and let things play out."
"That’s a significant shift, David. By noticing the pattern without immediately acting on it, you’re giving yourself space to step back. How has that felt—letting go of the need to intervene?"

"It’s a mix. Part of me feels relieved, like I don’t have to carry everything. But another part of me feels anxious, like I’m abandoning my responsibility. It’s hard to shake that feeling, even though I know it’s not all on me."

"That anxiety makes sense, especially when this role has been such a big part of your life. It might feel like you're losing something essential by stepping back, but what do you think you’re gaining by not always stepping in?"

[pauses] "I think I’m gaining some peace. I’m not as stressed, and I don’t feel as overwhelmed. But it’s also strange because I’ve always defined myself by how well I can keep things together. It feels like I’m losing a part of who I am."

"That feeling of losing a part of yourself is powerful. It’s like you’re stepping into the unknown, where your identity isn’t tied to being the fixer. How do you feel about exploring who you are outside of that role?"

"I think it’s what I need to do, but it’s scary. I don’t know who I am without that. I’ve spent my whole life making sure everyone else is okay, and now I’m trying to figure out what I need. But I don’t even know where to start."

"That uncertainty is a natural part of the process, David. It’s like stepping into uncharted territory. What would it feel like to start by asking yourself what brings you peace or fulfillment, rather than what you can fix for others?"

"I’ve thought about that, but I don’t have any clear answers yet. I’ve been so focused on being there for everyone else that I’ve never really taken the time to think about what I want. Maybe it’s time I figure that out."

"That’s a key realization. The fact that you’re even asking these questions is a sign that you’re ready to explore what you need. How do you feel about giving yourself permission to start discovering that—without pressure to have all the answers right away?"

"It’s hard to give myself that permission, but I know I need to. I’ve been so used to having all the answers or at least pretending like I do. But now, I’m starting to realize that it’s okay not to know everything."

"That’s a major shift, David—letting go of the need to have all the answers. It allows you to be more open to discovering what feels right for you, rather than trying to control the outcome. How does that idea sit with you?"
"It’s a relief, honestly. I’ve been holding onto this idea that I have to be in control all the time, and it’s exhausting. Letting go of that feels like I can finally breathe."

"That’s a powerful image—finally being able to breathe. It sounds like by releasing control, you’re giving yourself space to exist more freely. How do you think this will impact your relationships, especially with your wife and kids?"

"I think it’s already making a difference. I’m more present with the kids, and I’m not as stressed about trying to keep things perfect. With my wife, things are still tense, but I feel like I’m not as reactive anymore. I’m trying to just be with her, instead of always trying to fix what’s wrong."
"That’s a meaningful shift—moving from fixing to simply being present. How has that felt for you, especially with your wife? Does it change the dynamic between you?"

"It does, but it’s subtle. We’re still not in a great place, but I feel like I’m less focused on trying to fix her problems or make everything okay. Instead, I’m just listening more, even when it’s hard to hear what she’s saying."

"That’s a big change, David. Listening without the need to fix can create space for deeper connection, even when things are difficult. How does it feel to just sit with her emotions, without rushing to find a solution?"
"It’s uncomfortable, but in a good way. I’m realizing that sometimes she doesn’t need me to solve anything—she just wants me to hear her. That’s been hard for me to accept, but I think it’s helping."

"That’s a key insight—recognizing that sometimes presence is more valuable than solutions. How do you feel about continuing to cultivate that kind of emotional presence in your relationship with her and the kids?"

"I think it’s the right path. It feels more honest, and I’m less exhausted because I’m not constantly trying to fix everything. It’s a work in progress, but I think we’re moving in the right direction."

"That’s a huge step forward. You’re allowing yourself to shift from doing to being, and that’s a powerful change. Now, I’d like to explore something deeper—your emotional experiences as a child. We’ve talked a lot about how you took on the role of peacemaker. What were the emotions you didn’t express back then, the ones you had to hold in?"

[pauses, thinking deeply] "I think I was angry a lot, but I never showed it. I hated the fights, hated how it made me feel powerless. But I couldn’t show that anger because it felt like I had to be the one holding everything together."
"That’s a lot to carry as a child—anger, powerlessness, and the sense that you had to be the glue holding things together. How do you feel about connecting with that anger now, in your adult life?"

"It’s weird because I’ve always pushed it down. Even now, when I get angry, I just shove it aside and try to stay calm. But I think I’m starting to realize that maybe that anger is still there, and I need to deal with it."

"That’s an important realization, David. Anger, when suppressed, can build up and manifest in other ways—like stress, anxiety, or burnout. How do you feel about finding a healthy way to express that anger, without letting it overwhelm you?"

"I think I need to. I’ve never really given myself permission to be angry. It’s like I’ve always been afraid that if I let it out, it’ll spiral out of control. But maybe there’s a way to express it without letting it take over."

"Exactly. Anger doesn’t have to be destructive. It can be a signal that something needs to change, or that a boundary has been crossed. How do you feel about exploring ways to give that anger a voice in a safe and constructive way?"

"I think it’s worth trying. I’ve held it in for so long that I don’t even know what it would feel like to express it. But I’m willing to give it a shot, if it means letting go of some of this weight I’ve been carrying."

"That’s a powerful step, David—acknowledging that your anger is valid and deserves to be expressed. We can work together to find ways for you to explore that anger safely. How does it feel to know that you don’t have to suppress those emotions anymore?"

"It’s a relief, but also kind of scary. I’ve built my whole life around keeping things calm and peaceful, and now I’m realizing that maybe that’s not what I need. Maybe it’s okay to let things get messy sometimes."

"That’s a profound realization—accepting that life doesn’t always have to be calm or peaceful, and that emotions, even messy ones, are part of the human experience. How do you feel about embracing that messiness, both in yourself and in your relationships?"
"I think it’s going to take time, but I’m starting to see that maybe it’s what I need. I’ve spent so long trying to avoid conflict, but maybe facing it head-on is the only way to really grow."

"That’s a powerful insight, David. By embracing the messiness of life and allowing yourself to feel and express all your emotions, you’re giving yourself the freedom to grow emotionally. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"

"I feel like I’m finally starting to understand what I need to do. It’s not about fixing everything—it’s about letting myself feel, even when it’s uncomfortable. I know it’s going to take time, but I feel more hopeful."

"That’s a significant breakthrough, David. You’re allowing yourself to step into your emotions, and that’s an important part of your healing process. We’ll continue exploring this in future sessions, and you’re doing important emotional work."

In session 28, David reflects on his progress with his children and his ongoing difficulties with Sarah. "Welcome back, David. Last time we explored how you’ve been letting go of the fixer role, and how that’s begun to shift your relationships at home. Before we dive deeper today, how have things been with you and your family over the past week?"

"That sounds like a thoughtful way to present it. Focusing on understanding and clarity rather than resolution can help take some of the pressure off. How do you think Sarah might respond to that invitation?"

"I think she might be open to it now. Things have been calmer between us, and she’s been more engaged with the kids, which I think has taken some of the pressure off of us. I’ll talk to her this week and see how she feels."

"That sounds like a solid plan. Now that you’re prepared to approach Sarah with this invitation, I’d like to shift our focus a bit. We’ve spent a lot of time discussing your role in the marriage, but I want to go deeper into how your childhood experiences might still be influencing your relationships today. When you think about your parents’ relationship, particularly their conflicts, do you see any parallels to how you’ve navigated your own marriage?"

[pauses, thinking deeply] "Yeah, I do. My parents fought a lot when I was younger, but they never divorced. I always wondered why they stayed together when they clearly weren’t happy. I guess that stuck with me—this idea that you’re supposed to stick it out, no matter how bad it gets. And that’s what I’ve been doing with Sarah—just staying, even when things are falling apart."

"That’s a powerful connection. It seems like the model your parents set for staying together, despite the conflict, shaped your belief that enduring the struggle was the only option. How do you feel about the idea that leaving, or allowing things to change, isn’t necessarily a failure?"

[sighs] "It’s hard to wrap my head around that. I’ve always seen leaving as giving up, and that’s something I’ve tried to avoid my whole life. But now… maybe it’s not about giving up. Maybe it’s about letting go of something that’s not working anymore."

"That’s an important shift in perspective, David. Letting go doesn’t have to mean failure—it can be about choosing what’s healthiest for you, Sarah, and your children. How does it feel to consider that possibility?"
"It feels strange, but also like a weight off my shoulders. I’ve been carrying this burden of trying to make everything work, but maybe it’s time to acknowledge that it’s okay to let go."

"That’s a profound realization. By giving yourself permission to let go, you’re allowing space for something new—whether that’s a new dynamic in your relationship with Sarah, or a new chapter in your life. How do you feel about continuing to explore that possibility?"
"I think I’m ready to. I’ve been holding onto this idea of what our marriage should be for so long that I haven’t really considered what it actually is, and whether that’s enough."

"That’s a powerful insight. The gap between what you imagined and what the reality is can be hard to face, but it’s also the first step toward making decisions that are more aligned with your current needs. How do you think letting go of that old ideal will affect your relationship with Sarah moving forward?"

"I think it’ll take some of the pressure off. We’ve both been trying to live up to this idea of what a marriage should be, but maybe we just need to accept that things have changed. Whether that means we stay together or not, I think we need to stop pretending everything’s okay."

"That’s a significant shift. By letting go of that ideal, you’re creating space for more honest conversations about what you both want and need now, rather than what you thought you should have. How does it feel to step into that space of honesty, even if it’s uncomfortable?"
[pauses, sighing] "It’s scary, but also freeing. I’ve been so afraid of what might happen if we really talk about our marriage, but I think it’s time. We can’t keep avoiding it."

"That’s an important realization, David. Avoiding the conversation may have kept things stable for a while, but it also prevented deeper emotional clarity. How do you feel about the idea that facing these hard truths might actually bring more peace, regardless of the outcome?"

"I think that’s what I need to hear. I’ve been so focused on keeping everything together that I haven’t thought about what might happen if we just… let go of the things that aren’t working. Maybe that’s the only way to really move forward."

"That’s a powerful insight. Sometimes letting go of what isn’t working creates space for something better, whether that’s in the form of a healthier relationship or a peaceful separation. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session, knowing you’re about to take this next step?"

"I feel more ready. It’s still scary, but I think I’m finally starting to see that it’s okay to let go, to stop holding onto something that’s not working. I’m going to talk to Sarah about coming to a session. I think we both need it."

"That’s a brave step, David. You’ve come a long way in understanding your emotional patterns and making space for change. We’ll be here to support both of you, whether she decides to come or not. You’re making important progress."

In session 29, Sarah joins David in therapy for the first time. Both express feeling disconnected and unsure about the future of their relationship. [smiling warmly] "Welcome, Sarah. I’m really glad you could join us today. I know it takes a lot to step into this space, especially when things feel so uncertain. pauses, thinking "I guess I’m hoping for some clarity. Things have been tense between us for a long time, and I don’t really know where we stand anymore. I want to understand if there’s still a future for us or if we’re just holding onto something that’s not working."

takes a deep breath "I think that’s what we need. I’ve been feeling the same way. It’s like we’re living separate lives under the same roof, and I don’t know how much longer we can keep doing that. I’ve been afraid to really face the truth, but I think it’s time we stop avoiding it."

"It sounds like you’re both in a place where you’re ready to confront the reality of your relationship, even if it’s hard. That’s a significant first step. Sarah, you mentioned feeling like you’re not sure where you stand. Can you share more about what that uncertainty looks like for you?"

pauses, looking at David before speaking "I feel like we’ve grown apart. We used to be so close—we’d talk about everything, stay up late just being together.
