nodding, listening intently "I’ve felt that too. It’s like we’re just going through the motions, doing what we need to do for the kids, but not really connecting with each other."

"That sense of growing apart can feel like a huge emotional distance, especially when the focus has shifted primarily to practical matters. Sarah, when did you start noticing that distance between you?"

"I don’t know if there was a specific moment, but after Lily was born, things just started to change. We were both so focused on the kids, and I think we stopped making time for each other. And after Emily came, it got even harder. It wasn’t intentional, but we just drifted."
frowning "Yeah, I think that’s when it started for me too. We were so overwhelmed with the kids and work that it felt like we didn’t have any energy left for each other."

"It sounds like the responsibilities of parenting, work, and life slowly shifted your focus away from each other, and over time, that distance became more noticeable. How have both of you felt about the lack of connection—has it been something you’ve talked about, or has it been more of an unspoken tension?"

glancing at David "We haven’t really talked about it. I think we both felt it, but neither of us wanted to bring it up. It was just easier to focus on the kids or the day-to-day stuff. But I’ve been feeling more and more like we’re just roommates."
sighs "Yeah, I’ve been feeling that too. I didn’t bring it up because I didn’t want to make things worse. I thought if I just kept going, it would somehow get better. But it hasn’t."

"It’s common to avoid those difficult conversations, especially when life is busy and there are so many responsibilities. But what I’m hearing is that you’ve both been feeling this disconnection for a long time. How do you feel about starting to talk about it openly now, even if it’s uncomfortable?"
nodding slowly "I think we have to. We can’t keep pretending everything’s fine when it’s not. I’m tired of feeling like this."
pauses "Me too. I don’t want to keep avoiding it. I want to understand where we are and if we can fix this or if we’re just holding onto something that’s not working anymore."

"That’s an important step—to openly acknowledge that things aren’t fine and that avoiding the conversation isn’t helping. Now that we’re starting to talk about it, I’d like to ask each of you what you think has been the most challenging part of your relationship recently. Sarah, would you like to start?"

pauses, thinking carefully "I think the hardest part has been feeling like we’ve lost the emotional connection. We used to be so in sync, but now it feels like we’re on completely different pages. I miss the way we used to talk and laugh together, but I don’t know if we can get back to that."

quietly "I miss that too. I feel like we’ve just been existing next to each other, but not really together. The hardest part for me has been feeling like I’m failing—not just as a husband, but as a father too. I don’t want the kids to grow up in a home where their parents are distant."

"It sounds like you’re both mourning the loss of that emotional closeness, and there’s a shared sense of sadness around the way things have changed. How do you feel about the possibility of rebuilding that connection, even though things are different now?"
"I don’t know. Part of me wants to, but part of me wonders if we’re too far gone. It’s been so long since we’ve really connected. I don’t even know where we’d start."

nodding "That’s what I’m afraid of too. I want to try, but I don’t know if we can get back to where we were. It feels like so much has happened, and we’re not the same people we were when we first got together."

"It’s understandable to feel uncertain about whether you can rebuild the connection, especially after so much time has passed. But it’s also important to recognize that rebuilding doesn’t mean going back to who you were—it’s about finding a new way to connect as the people you are now. How do you feel about exploring that possibility?"
hesitant "I think it’s worth exploring, but I don’t want to get my hopes up. I’ve been feeling so disconnected for so long that it’s hard to imagine things being different."

"I get that. I don’t want to put pressure on us to fix everything overnight. But I think if we both want to try, maybe we can start small. We don’t have to go back to how things were—we can figure out a new way to be together."

"That’s a healthy approach—starting small and focusing on finding new ways to connect, rather than trying to force things to go back to how they used to be. It’s about discovering what works for both of you now, given everything you’ve been through. How do you both feel about taking some time, after today, to have smaller, more intentional conversations, just the two of you?"
nodding "I think that would help. We’ve been avoiding each other emotionally, and maybe if we start talking again—really talking—it could make a difference."
"I agree. We need to start somewhere. Even if it’s just talking for a few minutes each day without distractions, it could help us reconnect."

"That’s a great first step. It doesn’t have to be a grand gesture—just small, meaningful moments where you can begin to rebuild trust and connection. And remember, it’s okay if it feels awkward or difficult at first. This is a new chapter, and it’s okay to take it one step at a time. How are you both feeling about the idea of creating those moments?"
"I think it’s a good idea. I’m willing to try."
"Same here. I’m ready to put in the effort, even if it’s uncomfortable at first."

In session 30, David and Sarah continue their joint therapy, with Sarah revealing how emotionally drained and lost she feels in her roles as a wife and mother. David admits he didn’t fully understand how much Sarah was carrying and expresses a desire to reconnect. They both share fears of whether their relationship can be repaired after so much emotional distance. The therapist guides them toward identifying what they need from each other, with Sarah wanting to feel like a priority in David’s life, and David committing to being more emotionally present and consistent. They agree to take small steps toward rebuilding their connection.

[settling in, looking at both David and Sarah] "Welcome back, both of you. I want to acknowledge the courage it took to be here together, ready to dig deeper into the complexities of your relationship. Today, I want to give both of you the space to engage with each other as much as you feel comfortable. This isn’t just about us three talking in turns—there will be moments where I step back and let you both express yourselves to one another. How are you both feeling coming into this session?"

[glancing at David, then Dr. Shrink] "I’m anxious, honestly. We’ve been talking more at home, but it’s been… hard. I know we need to do this, but it still feels like there’s this huge wall between us."

nodding slightly, looking at Sarah with concern "Yeah, I feel that too. It’s like every conversation we have is careful—like we’re afraid to say the wrong thing or bring up something that’ll make things worse."

"That makes sense. You’ve both been navigating a lot of tension for a long time, and the fear of creating more conflict can make it difficult to have honest conversations. But today, I want to encourage you to lean into that discomfort. It’s okay to feel unsure or even frustrated. This is a space where you can voice those fears openly."
[looking directly at David] "I’m scared, David. I’m scared of what we’ve become. It feels like we’re barely holding on, and I don’t know if we can get back to what we had."

pausing, meeting Sarah’s eyes "I know… I’ve been scared too. Scared of losing you. Scared that maybe we’re beyond repair. But I also don’t want to give up without trying. We haven’t really talked about what we want—what we need from each other."
[sighing] "I don’t know what I want, David. That’s part of the problem. I’m exhausted—emotionally drained. I don’t know if I have anything left to give."

[speaking gently] "Sarah, that exhaustion is something I want to focus on for a moment. It sounds like you’ve been carrying a lot of emotional weight for a long time. Can you share more about what that feels like?"

[thinking, fidgeting with her hands] "It feels like I’ve been doing everything I can to keep things together—for the kids, for the house, for us—and I’m just… tired. I love David, but I feel like I’ve lost myself in all of it. I don’t even recognize who I am anymore."

[looking down, frowning] "I didn’t realize you felt that way. I’ve been so caught up in my own head that I didn’t see how much pressure you’ve been under. I’ve been feeling like a failure as a husband, but I didn’t stop to think about how that was affecting you."

[nodding thoughtfully] "It sounds like both of you have been carrying your own burdens, but not necessarily sharing them with each other. Sarah, when you say you feel like you’ve lost yourself, what do you mean by that?"

[pauses, thinking deeply] "I used to be so independent, so sure of myself. I had my career, my interests, my identity. But after the kids came, everything shifted. Suddenly, I was a mom first, and everything else just… disappeared. And somewhere along the way, I stopped being Sarah. I became ‘Mom’ and ‘David’s wife,’ and nothing else."

[looking pained] "I never meant for you to feel like that. I’ve been so wrapped up in trying to keep everything together that I didn’t see how much you were giving up. I thought we were in this together, but now I realize you’ve been feeling alone."

[voice softens] "I have been feeling alone, David. But I didn’t know how to tell you. Every time I tried to talk to you about how I was feeling, it seemed like you were so stressed yourself that I didn’t want to add to it. So, I just kept it inside."
[sighing, running his hand through his hair] "I wish you’d told me. I know I’ve been distant, but I’ve always cared about how you feel. I just didn’t know how to deal with everything either."

"This is an important moment for both of you. Sarah, you’ve been holding in your feelings for a long time, and David, it sounds like you’ve been carrying your own sense of failure and guilt without really expressing it. What would it feel like, right now, for both of you to speak openly about what you need from each other moving forward—without the pressure to fix it all at once?"

[pauses, looking at David] "I need… I need to feel like I matter to you, David. Not just as the mother of your children or the person you share a house with, but as a partner—as someone you care about beyond the day-to-day stuff."

[listening closely, nodding slowly] "I hear you. I haven’t been good at showing that, but I do care, Sarah. I’ve been so wrapped up in my own head, trying to fix everything, that I didn’t stop to think about what you needed from me as a husband. I need to do better at making you feel like a priority."
[leaning forward slightly] "David, can you expand on that? What does it mean to you to make Sarah a priority? What would that look like in your relationship?"

[thinking carefully] "I think it means being present—really present when we’re together. Not just going through the motions or focusing on the kids or work, but actually spending time together, talking, connecting. I want to make time for us, like we used to, even if it’s just small things—going for a walk, sitting and talking after the kids are in bed. I need to show her that she still matters to me."
[tears welling up] "I’d like that, David. I’ve missed that connection with you. It’s been so long since we’ve just… been together, without the distractions or the stress."

[looking directly at Sarah] "I’ve missed it too. And I know I haven’t been the best partner. I’ve let my own fears and anxieties get in the way of being there for you. But I want to change that. I want us to find a way to reconnect."
[voice breaking slightly] "I want that too. But I’m scared, David. I’m scared that we’ve grown so far apart that it’s too late."

[speaking softly] "That fear is very real, and it’s okay to acknowledge it. Rebuilding connection after so much distance takes time and effort from both of you. But the fact that you’re both expressing a desire to reconnect is a hopeful sign. It’s not about erasing the past or trying to go back to how things were—it’s about building something new, together. Sarah, what would help you feel like David is really committed to that?"

[thinking] "I think I need to see him make the effort, consistently. I need to see that he’s willing to put in the work, not just for a week or two, but long-term. I need to know that this isn’t just about us trying to fix things for the sake of the kids or because it’s what we think we should do."

[nodding earnestly] "I understand. I want to show you that I’m in this for the long haul, not just to patch things up for the moment. I know it’s going to take time, but I’m willing to do whatever it takes to make this work."

[looking between them] "It’s clear that both of you are willing to try, and that’s a strong foundation to start from. But let’s take a moment to acknowledge that there will be setbacks—times when it feels hard, or when old patterns resurface. How do you feel about navigating those moments when they happen?"

[pauses, thinking deeply] "I think it’s going to be hard. We’ve been in these patterns for so long that it’ll be tough to break them. But if David’s really committed, and if we can both be patient with each other, I think we can get through it."
"I agree. I know there will be tough days, but I’m ready to face them with you. I don’t want to go back to just avoiding the hard stuff. I want us to work through it, together."

[smiling slightly] "That willingness to face the hard days together is key. It’s about showing up, even when things are difficult. Now, let’s shift the conversation a bit. David, I want you to talk directly to Sarah about what you need from her as you both move forward."

[turning to Sarah] "I need… I need you to trust that I’m really trying. I know I’ve let you down before, and I know I’ve been distant, but I’m ready to make things right. I need you to believe that we can get through this, even if it’s hard. And I need us to start talking more, really talking, like we used to."

[listening closely, wiping away a tear] "I hear you, David. And I want to believe that we can get through this. But I need time—to see that the changes are real. I need to know that you’re in this with me, for the long term."
"I am, Sarah. I’m not going anywhere."

[crying now, her voice shaking] "I don’t doubt that you care, David. I know you love me. But it feels like we’ve been living two separate lives for so long. I don’t know how to get back to being... us."

[crying softly now, his voice thick with emotion] "I miss us too. I miss just being with you, without all the stress, without all the walls between us. I want to find a way back, but I don’t know how."

[nodding earnestly, through tears] "I hear you. I haven’t been there the way I should have been. I’ve let you carry too much, and that’s not fair. I want to do better, Sarah. I want to be your partner again, not just in name, but really."

[nodding] "This is where rebuilding starts—through small, consistent actions that show commitment. Sarah, you mentioned feeling like you’ve been carrying everything alone. [thinking] "It would help. I need to feel like we’re both in this, that I’m not just holding everything together by myself. I need David to be there, not just physically, but emotionally."
"I’m ready to be that for you, Sarah. I know I’ve been emotionally distant, but I don’t want to be anymore. I want to be there for you, in every way."
[wiping her tears, nodding slowly] "I want to believe that, David. I really do. But I need to see it. I need to feel it."

"This is a powerful moment for both of you. There’s so much emotion here—grief over what’s been lost, but also hope for what could be rebuilt. Sarah, you’ve expressed what you need from David. David, you’ve acknowledged your role and your willingness to change. How do you both feel about taking this one step at a time, focusing on small, intentional efforts to reconnect?"
"I think that’s the only way we can do it. We’ve been so far apart for so long that it’s going to take time to rebuild."

[tears welling up again] "I hear you, Sarah. I do. And I’m sorry that I haven’t been the partner you needed. I want to be. I’m ready to be. I know I’ve let you down, but I don’t want to keep doing that."

"This is a profound moment of recognition, David. You’re acknowledging the emotional burden Sarah has been carrying, and Sarah, you’re expressing your need for partnership. How do you feel, Sarah, hearing David express his commitment to being a better partner?"

[pauses, looking at David] "It gives me hope. But I’m still scared. We’ve had moments like this before, where things seemed like they were going to change, but then they didn’t. I need to believe that this time will be different."

[reaching for Sarah’s hand hesitantly] "I know I’ve said it before, but I’m different now. I’ve been working on myself, and I’m starting to understand how much I’ve been holding back emotionally. I know it’s not enough to say it—I have to show it."
[taking his hand, tears in her eyes] "I want to believe that, David. I do. I just don’t know if I can handle being disappointed again."

"That’s a very real fear, Sarah—the fear of disappointment. David, how do you feel about Sarah’s hesitation and her need to see consistent change over time?"

[nodding, squeezing her hand gently] "I get it. I’ve let her down before, so it makes sense that she’d be hesitant. But I’m ready to do whatever it takes to prove to her that I’m serious. Not just with words, but with actions. I know it’s going to take time, but I’m not going anywhere."
[looking down, her voice soft] "I need time, David. I need time to see if we can really rebuild what we lost. I want to, but I can’t rush this. I need to feel safe again."

I want to shift focus for a moment—David, we’ve talked a lot about how you’ve felt like a failure in the relationship. Can you share more about where that sense of failure comes from?"

[pausing, wiping his eyes] "I think… I’ve always felt like I wasn’t good enough. Like no matter how hard I tried, I was always falling short. It started when I was a kid. My parents fought all the time, and I always felt like it was my job to keep the peace. But I never could. I carried that into my marriage with Sarah—I felt like it was my job to make everything okay, but I’ve been failing at that too."

[looking at David, her voice softer now] "You’re not failing, David. I know you’ve been trying, but it’s not all on you. I’ve been carrying things too. Maybe we’ve both been trying too hard in different ways, and that’s what’s pulling us apart."
[his voice thick with emotion] "I just don’t want to feel like I’m letting you down anymore. I’ve felt like I’m always one step behind—never doing enough, never being enough."

[gently] "David, that sense of not being enough is deeply rooted in your childhood experiences. You took on the role of trying to keep the peace between your parents, and when you couldn’t, you felt like you were failing. That pattern has carried into your adult life, especially in your marriage with Sarah. You’ve been trying to fix things, but you’ve also been carrying this belief that you’re somehow not enough, no matter how hard you try. How does that resonate with you?"

[pausing, his voice trembling] "It makes sense. I always felt like if I could just do more—be better—then things would get better. But I’ve been carrying this weight for so long that I don’t even know what it feels like to just... be. I’ve been trying so hard to hold everything together, but I’m exhausted. And I feel like I’ve been failing Sarah because I’m not the husband or father I want to be."

[gently, her hand still on his] "David, you’re not failing. You’ve been doing your best. I see that now. But I think we’ve both been trying to fix everything by ourselves, without really talking to each other about what we need. We’ve been on our own islands, even though we’re in the same house."

"That image of being on your own islands while being in the same house is powerful, Sarah. You’ve both been struggling, but instead of turning to each other, you’ve been trying to solve things on your own. How do you think it would feel to start reaching out to each other again, rather than trying to carry everything alone?"
[sighing deeply] "It would be a relief, honestly. I’ve felt so alone for so long. It would feel good to know that David is really there with me, not just physically but emotionally."

[nodding slowly] "I want that too. I don’t want to keep doing this alone. I’ve been so caught up in my own head, trying to figure out how to fix everything, but I don’t want to carry this by myself anymore."

"It sounds like you’re both realizing that the emotional distance between you hasn’t just been about the relationship itself—it’s also been about the roles you’ve each taken on, feeling like you had to carry the weight alone. How does it feel to know that you don’t have to keep doing that?"

[pauses, thinking deeply] "It’s strange. I’ve always felt like I had to be the one holding everything together, but hearing Sarah say that she feels the same way… it makes me realize how much we’ve both been struggling. I don’t want to keep carrying this weight by myself. I want us to figure it out together."
[nodding, her eyes softening] "Me too. I don’t want to feel like I’m alone in this anymore. I want to feel like we’re partners again, not just two people living in the same house."
[reaching for her hand again, his voice more steady] "We can do this, Sarah. I know it’s not going to be easy, but I’m ready to do whatever it takes. I don’t want us to keep drifting apart."
[looking at him with tears in her eyes] "I want that too, David. I miss you. I miss us. But I’m scared—scared that it won’t last, scared that we’ll fall back into the same patterns."
[tearing up as well] "I’m scared too. But I’m willing to face that fear with you. I don’t want to lose you, Sarah. I’m ready to change, not just for a little while, but for good."

"This is a crucial moment for both of you. You’re expressing your fears openly, but you’re also expressing your commitment to each other. Sarah, you’ve shared your fear of falling back into old patterns, and David, you’ve acknowledged that fear but are ready to move forward. What do you think it would look like for both of you to break those old patterns and create new ones—together?"

[thinking for a moment, wiping her tears] "I think it would mean really talking to each other, not just about the kids or the house, but about us—how we’re feeling, what we need from each other. We’ve avoided those conversations for so long because they’re hard, but maybe that’s what we need to do more of."

[nodding] "I agree. I’ve avoided talking about my feelings because I didn’t want to add more stress, but I see now that avoiding it has only made things worse. We need to start being honest with each other, even when it’s uncomfortable."

"It sounds like you’re both ready to create a new way of communicating—one that’s based on honesty and emotional presence, rather than avoiding the tough conversations. How do you feel about committing to making time for those conversations, even when life gets busy?"
[nodding slowly] "I think we have to. We can’t keep pushing it aside. If we don’t make time for each other, we’re just going to end up right back where we started."
"I’m with you. We’ve been going through the motions for too long. I want us to really connect again, not just for the kids, but for us."

"That’s a crucial point, David. Rebuilding your connection isn’t just about creating a stable home for your children—it’s about rediscovering each other as partners. Sarah, how do you feel about exploring what that partnership looks like now, as the people you’ve become over the years, rather than who you used to be?"

[pausing, thinking carefully] "I think that’s what we need to do. We’ve both changed, and I’ve been holding onto this idea of who we were when we first got together. But we’re different now. I think we need to figure out how to love each other as we are now, not as we were."

[nodding thoughtfully] "I’ve been holding onto that idea too. I’ve been trying to get back to who we were, but maybe that’s not possible—or even necessary. Maybe we just need to figure out how to move forward as we are now."

"That’s a powerful realization. Trying to go back to who you were can create pressure and disappointment when things don’t feel the same. But moving forward with the people you’ve become—acknowledging the growth, the changes, the challenges—that’s where you can build a new, stronger connection. How do you both feel about letting go of the past version of your relationship and focusing on building something new together?"
[tears welling up again, but smiling slightly] "I think that’s what we need to do. We can’t keep trying to go back. I’m ready to start building something new with you, David."
[smiling softly through his own tears] "Me too. I don’t want to go back. I want us to create something even better."

"That’s a beautiful place to be—acknowledging the past, but not letting it dictate your future. This is where real healing can begin. Now that you’re both committed to building something new, what’s one small step you can take, starting today, to move in that direction?"

[thinking] "I think we need to make time for each other, even if it’s just a few minutes a day. We’ve been so focused on the kids and work that we haven’t made time for us. I want us to start talking more, like we used to."
[nodding in agreement] "I’m with you. We need to prioritize each other, even when things get busy. I’m ready to make that a part of our daily life."

"That’s a wonderful first step—making time for each other, even in small ways, can create the space for deeper connection. How do you feel about checking in with each other regularly, not just about the logistics of life, but about how you’re feeling emotionally?"
"I think that would help. We’ve been so disconnected that even asking how each other’s day was would be a good start."
"I agree. We’ve been running on autopilot for so long. I want to be more intentional about connecting with you, Sarah."

"It’s about those small, intentional moments—making space for each other in the everyday. You’re both on the same page about wanting to rebuild, and that’s the foundation you need. As we wrap up today’s session, how are you both feeling about the steps you’ve discussed?"
[nodding slowly] "I feel hopeful. It’s going to be hard, but I’m ready to try."
"I’m hopeful too. I know it’s not going to be easy, but I’m committed. I don’t want to lose what we have."

In session 33, David and Sarah begin to address their lingering fears and emotional distance. [smiling slightly] "It’s about sharing the emotional load together, rather than feeling like either of you has to carry it alone. [nodding as well] "I’m with you. I’m ready to put in the work, no matter how long it takes."

In session 38, David reflects on his role as the 'fixer' in both his marriage and family life. "It sounds like the emotional drain from work is leaving you with very little to give at home. Let’s talk about Sarah for a moment. You mentioned earlier that one of your concerns is making sure she’s not overwhelmed. How are you feeling about your role in supporting her?"

[leaning in slightly] "That’s significant, David. You learned from a young age that stepping in and taking control was necessary to keep things stable. "It makes sense, given your history, that you would carry that pattern into adulthood. You took on the role of protector and stabilizer at a young age, and it’s continued into your role as a husband and father. But here’s the thing

[settling into the final part of the session, his tone becoming more focused and reflective] "As we move into the last part of our session, I’d like to bring our focus to some deeper issues.
